Function.Description: This function gets the value at a specific point in time from a channel struct.

Parameter.Name: channel_struct
Parameter.Description: The struct pointer for the channel to evaluate.

Parameter.Name: posx
Parameter.Description: The position in time to check (from 0 to 1).

Function.Name: animcurve_channel_evaluate

Function.Description: This function creates a new animation curve channel struct.
Function.Name: animcurve_channel_new

Function.Description: This function creates an empty animation curve struct, ready for you to populate with channel data.
Function.Name: animcurve_create

Function.Description: This function destroys an animation curve previously created with the function animcurve_create().

Parameter.Name: curve_struct
Parameter.Description: The pointer to the curve struct to destroy.

Function.Name: animcurve_destroy

Function.Description: This function returns a struct containing all the data for the given animation curve.

Parameter.Name: curve_id
Parameter.Description: The asset ID (index) of the animation curve to get.

Function.Name: animcurve_get

Function.Description: This function returns the struct containing the channel data for the channel specified in an animation curve asset or struct (as returned by animcurve_get()).

Parameter.Name: curve_struct_or_id
Parameter.Description: The ID or struct pointer of the animation curve to target

Parameter.Name: channel_name_or_index
Parameter.Description: The channel name (a string) or the channel index (an integer).

Function.Name: animcurve_get_channel

Function.Description:
This function returns the index value for any given animation curve channel.
			
			You supply the animation curve ID or struct, where the curve ID is the name of the animation curve as it was defined in the Asset Browser, or the struct pointer as returned by the function animcurve_create(). You then supply the name of the channel, as a string, and the function will return the index value associated with that channel. Note that if the curve or channel does not exist then you will get an error.

Parameter.Name: curve_struct_or_id
Parameter.Description: The ID or struct pointer of the animation curve to target

Parameter.Name: channel_name
Parameter.Description: The channel name (a string).

Function.Name: animcurve_get_channel_index

Function.Description: This function creates a new points struct (posx, value) to be added to an animation curve channel.
Function.Name: animcurve_point_new

Function.Description:
This function adds one or more tag strings to any asset from the Asset Browser.
			
			You supply either the asset name (as a string) or its asset index, as well as either a single tag string or an array where each item is a single tag string. If you supply an asset index value, then you will need to supply the optional asset type argument (a constant), as assets of different types can have the same index, even though they cannot have the same name.

Parameter.Name: name_or_index
Parameter.Description: The name of the asset (a string) or its index value (an integer).

Parameter.Name: tags
Parameter.Description: A single asset tag string or an array with various asset tags.

Parameter.Name: asset_type
Parameter.Description: OPTIONAL! The type of asset to set the tags on, only used when supplying an index for the first argument.

Function.Name: asset_add_tags

Function.Description:
This function clears all tags present on the given asset from the Asset Browser and returns whether any tags were removed.
			
			You supply either the asset name (as a string) or its asset index, and if you supply an asset index value, then you will need to supply the optional asset type argument (a constant), as assets of different types can have the same index, even though they cannot have the same name.

Parameter.Name: name_or_index
Parameter.Description: The name of the asset (a string) or its index value (an integer).

Parameter.Name: asset_type
Parameter.Description: OPTIONAL! The type of asset to clear the tags from, only used when supplying an index for the first argument.

Function.Name: asset_clear_tags

Function.Description:
This function gets the unique identifying index for a game asset from its name.
			
			If the asset is not found, the function will return a value of -1, otherwise it will return the unique index id for the asset being checked. This id can then be used in other functions as you would any other index value, like the sprite_index or the path_index, for example. Please note that although this function can be used to reference assets from strings, you should always make sure that the asset exists before using it otherwise you may get errors that will crash your game.

Parameter.Name: name
Parameter.Description: The name of the game asset to get the index of (a string).

Function.Name: asset_get_index

Function.Description:
This function retrieves all tags assigned to an asset from the Asset Browser.
			
			You supply either the asset name (as a string) or its asset index, and the function will return an array of tags for that asset. If no tags are found or there is an error (ie: the name string given doesn't exist) then the returned array will be empty. If you supply an asset index value, then you will need to supply the optional asset type argument (a constant), as assets of different types can have the same index, even though they cannot have the same name.

Parameter.Name: name_or_index
Parameter.Description: The name of the asset (a string) or its index value (an integer).

Parameter.Name: asset_type
Parameter.Description: OPTIONAL! The type of asset to get the tags for, only used when supplying an index for the first argument.

Function.Name: asset_get_tags

Function.Description: This function gets the type of asset being referenced from its name (a string).

Parameter.Name: name
Parameter.Description: The name of the game asset to get the type of (a string).

Function.Name: asset_get_type

Function.Description: This function returns an array containing IDs of all existing assets of given type.

Parameter.Name: asset_type
Parameter.Description: The type of assets to retrieve an array of.

Function.Name: asset_get_ids

Function.Description:
This function checks if one or more tag strings is assigned to the given asset from the Asset Browser.
			
			You supply either the asset name (as a string) or its asset index, as well as either a single tag string or an array where each item is a single tag string. If you supply an asset index value, then you will need to supply the optional asset type argument (a constant), as assets of different types can have the same index, even though they cannot have the same name.

Parameter.Name: name_or_index
Parameter.Description: The name of the asset (a string) or its index value (an integer).

Parameter.Name: tags
Parameter.Description: A single asset tag string or an array with various asset tags.

Parameter.Name: asset_type
Parameter.Description: OPTIONAL! The type of asset to check the tags for, only used when supplying an index for the first argument.

Function.Name: asset_has_tags

Function.Description:
This function removes one or more tag strings to any asset from the Asset Browser.
			
			You supply either the asset name (as a string) or its asset index, as well as either a single tag string or an array where each item is a single tag string. If you supply an asset index value, then you will need to supply the optional asset type argument (a constant), as assets of different types can have the same index, even though they cannot have the same name.

Parameter.Name: name_or_index
Parameter.Description: The name of the asset (a string) or its index value (an integer).

Parameter.Name: tags
Parameter.Description: A single asset tag string or an array with various asset tags.

Parameter.Name: asset_type
Parameter.Description: OPTIONAL! The type of asset to remove the tags from, only used when supplying an index for the first argument.

Function.Name: asset_remove_tags

Function.Description:
This function retrieves the names of all assets that have been assigned the given tag or tags.
			
			You supply either a single tag string or an array, where each item in the array is a tag string. The function will return an array where each entry is the name (as a string) of the asset with the given tag. If you need the unique index for the asset, then you can use the function asset_get_index() along with the returned name. If there are no assets with the given tag(s), or if there is an error (e.g., the given tags do not exist), then an empty array will be returned.

Parameter.Name: tags
Parameter.Description: A single asset tag string or an array with various asset tags.

Function.Name: tag_get_assets

Function.Description:
This function gets all the assets of a given type that have the given tags assigned to them.
			
			You supply either a single tag (as a string) or an array, where each item in the array is a tag (as a string), as well as the type of asset to check.

Parameter.Name: tags
Parameter.Description: A single asset tag string or an array with various asset tags.

Parameter.Name: asset_type
Parameter.Description: An asset type constant (listed above)

Function.Name: tag_get_asset_ids

Function.Description: With this function you can set how many audio channels are available for playing audio in GameMaker. What this basically means is that you give the number of simultaneous sounds that can be played at any one time, and if the number exceeds the amount, those sounds with a lower priority are stopped to free up a channel for the sounds with a higher priority. You can use this function to optimise your game for devices as the lower the number of channels for audio the better the performance, but bear in mind that this may also cause noticeable cut off of certain sounds if many are played at once.

Parameter.Name: num
Parameter.Description: Number of available audio channels (default is 128).

Function.Name: audio_channel_num

Function.Description: With this function you can create a new sound index which can then be used in the regular audio functions to stream audio directly from an external OGG file source. The function requires the filename (which can be an included file, for example) and will return the new sound index for use. Note that after you no longer need the sound you should call the function audio_destroy_stream() with the sound index to remove it from memory otherwise you may get a memory leak which will slow down and eventually crash your game.

Parameter.Name: filename
Parameter.Description: The file (OGG only) to stream the audio from.

Function.Name: audio_create_stream

Function.Description: This function can be used to display debug information about the audio system, with true switching it on and false to switch it off. When you are debugging audio in this way, the overlay will show the following information:

Parameter.Name: enable
Parameter.Description: Enable (set to true) or disable (false) audio debugging.

Function.Name: audio_debug

Function.Description: If you have previously created an audio stream from a file using the function audio_create_stream() and no longer need that sound, you can call this function to delete it from memory. Any further calls to the sound index after it has been destroyed will give an error. It should be noted that this will free up the stream but on the target platform this may not show up in a memory manager. This is because GameMaker pools memory resources to prevent memory allocation overhead, and so the memory will remain allocated until required for something else or re-used for a new stream.

Parameter.Name: filename
Parameter.Description: The file to stream the audio from.

Function.Name: audio_destroy_stream

Function.Description: This function returns whether a sound exists (true) or not (false). Note that if the index you search for has not been initialised previously, this function will cause an error as it is searching for non-existent asset indices. The sound to check can either be a single instance of a sound (the index for individual sounds being played can be stored in a variable when using the audio_play_sound() or audio_play_sound_at() functions) or a sound asset.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the sound to check the existence of.

Function.Name: audio_exists

Function.Description: To add more versatility to the audio engine, GameMaker permits you to select the falloff model that suits your game. This model will be used for all the audio functions in the game or app, and so you should make sure that the model you choose is the correct one, as each one will affect how the listener perceives the sounds you play through emitters or with the function audio_play_sound_at.

Parameter.Name: model
Parameter.Description: The constant used to set the falloff model.

Function.Name: audio_falloff_set_model

Function.Description: With this function you can get the absolute value for the global volume of all sounds and music for a specific listener. The default listener index is 0, but you can use the function audio_get_listener_info() to get the different indices available for the target platform. The gain value returned is based on a linear scale from 0 (silent) to 1 (full volume). Note that on some platforms you can have a gain of greater than 1, although a value of 1 is considered "full volume" and anything greater may introduce audio clipping.

Parameter.Name: listenerindex
Parameter.Description: The index of the listener to get the gain of.

Function.Name: audio_get_master_gain

Function.Description: This function will return the name of a given audio resource as a string. The "index" value can be that of the resource itself (as seen in the Asset Browser) or the unique ID value that is given when you play the sound using, for example, audio_play_sound(). Note that the string returned is not the same as the resource ID and cannot be used to access the resource itself, so should only be used for displaying or error checking.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the sound to check.

Function.Name: audio_get_name

Function.Description: When adding audio to GameMaker it can be either streamed or in memory. If you need to know whether a given sound index is for streamed audio or not you can use this function which will return 1 for streamed, 0 for sound in memory, and -1 if there is any error or the index does not point to a valid sound resource.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the sound to check.

Function.Name: audio_get_type

Function.Description: This function will check the given sound to see if it is currently paused. The sound can either be a single instance of a sound (the index for individual sounds being played can be stored in a variable when using the audio_play_sound() or audio_play_sound_at() functions) or a sound asset, in which case all instances of the given sound will be checked and if any of them are paused the function will return true otherwise it will return false.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the sound to check.

Function.Name: audio_is_paused

Function.Description: This function will check the given sound to see if it is currently playing. The sound can either be a single instance of a sound (the index for individual sounds being played can be stored in a variable when using the audio_play_sound() or audio_play_sound_at() functions) or a sound asset, in which case all instances of the given sound will be checked and if any of them are playing the function will return true otherwise it will return false. Note that this function will still return true if the sound being checked has previously been paused using the audio_pause_sound() function.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the sound to check.

Function.Name: audio_is_playing

Function.Description: With this function you can set the absolute value for the global volume of all sounds and music. It is based on a linear scale from 0 (silent) to any value greater than 0, although normally you'd consider the maximum volume as 1. Anything over 1 can be used but, depending on the sound used and the platform being compiled to, you may get distortion or clipping when the sound is played back. This function will affect the relative volume of all sounds and music played from within your game.

Parameter.Name: gain
Parameter.Description: Value for the global volume (0 to 1).

Function.Name: audio_master_gain

Function.Description: With this function you can pause all sounds that are currently playing.
Function.Name: audio_pause_all

Function.Description: With this function you can pause any sound that is currently playing. The sound can either be a single instance of a sound (the index for individual sounds being played can be stored in a variable when using the audio_play_sound() or audio_play_sound_at() functions) or a sound asset, in which case all instances of the given sound will be paused.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the sound to pause.

Function.Name: audio_pause_sound

Function.Description: With this function you can play any sound resource in your game. You provide the sound index and assign it a priority, which is then used to determine how sounds are dealt with when the number of sounds playing is over the limit set by the function audio_channel_num(). Lower priority sounds will be stopped in favour of higher priority sounds, and the priority value can be any real number (the actual value is arbitrary, and can be from 0 to 1 or 0 to 100, as GameMaker will prioritize them the same). Note that when dealing with priority, the higher the number the higher the priority, such that a sound with priority 100 will be favoured over a sound with priority 1. The final argument is for making the sound loop and setting it to true will make the sound loop until it is stopped and setting it to false will play the sound once only.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the sound to play.

Parameter.Name: priority
Parameter.Description: Set the channel priority for the sound.

Parameter.Name: loop
Parameter.Description: Sets the sound to loop or not.

Parameter.Name: gain
Parameter.Description: Sets the gain of the sound played.

Parameter.Name: offset
Parameter.Description: Sets the start offset (in seconds) of the sound played.

Parameter.Name: pitch
Parameter.Description: Sets the pitch of the sound played.

Parameter.Name: listener_mask
Parameter.Description: Sets the listener mask of the sound played.

Function.Name: audio_play_sound

Function.Description: With this function you can play any sound resource at a given position within the audio space. You provide the sound index and then assign it a position within the 3D space. The default listener position is (0, 0, 0) so this means that if the listener has not been moved and you want the sound to come from the left (for example), you should set the x position to a negative value (for more information on setting the listener position see audio_listener_position()).

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the sound to play.

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x position.

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y position.

Parameter.Name: z
Parameter.Description: The z position.

Parameter.Name: falloff_ref
Parameter.Description: The falloff reference relative to the listener (clamp).

Parameter.Name: falloff_max
Parameter.Description: The maximum falloff distance relative to the listener.

Parameter.Name: falloff_factor
Parameter.Description: The falloff factor (default 1).

Parameter.Name: loop
Parameter.Description: Flags the sound as looping or not.

Parameter.Name: priority
Parameter.Description: Set the channel priority for the sound.

Parameter.Name: gain
Parameter.Description: Sets the gain of the sound played.

Parameter.Name: offset
Parameter.Description: Sets the start offset (in seconds) of the sound played.

Parameter.Name: pitch
Parameter.Description: Sets the pitch of the sound played.

Parameter.Name: listener_mask
Parameter.Description: Sets the listener mask of the sound played.

Function.Name: audio_play_sound_at

Function.Description: With this function you can play any sound resource in your game. You provide a struct which contains a set of required parameters as well as any additional playback parameters. Parameters not specified will fall back to their default values/behaviour.

Parameter.Name: params
Parameter.Description: A struct containing a set of playback parameters.

Function.Name: audio_play_sound_ext

Function.Description: With this function you can resume all sounds that have been paused previously.
Function.Name: audio_resume_all

Function.Description: With this function you can resume any sound that is currently paused (after using the function audio_pause_sound()). The sound can either be a single instance of a sound (the index for individual sounds being played can be stored in a variable when using the audio_play_sound() or audio_play_sound_at() functions) or a sound asset, in which case all instances of the given sound will be re-started.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the sound to resume.

Function.Name: audio_resume_sound

Function.Description: With this function you can set the absolute value for the global volume of all sounds and music for a specific listener. The default listener index is 0, but you can use the function audio_get_listener_info() to get the different indices available for the target platform. The gain value is based on a linear scale from 0 (silent) to 1 (full volume) and will affect the relative volume of all sounds and music played from within your game through that listener.

Parameter.Name: listenerindex
Parameter.Description: The index of the listener to set the gain on.

Parameter.Name: gain
Parameter.Description: Value for the global volume (0 to 1).

Function.Name: audio_set_master_gain

Function.Description: With this function you can fade a sound in or out over a given length of time, or it can be used to set the sound gain instantly. The time is measured in milliseconds, and the function requires that you input a final level of gain for the sound to have reached by the end of that time. This gain can be between 0 (silent) and any value greater than 0, although normally you'd consider the maximum volume as 1. Anything over 1 can be used but, depending on the sound used and the platform being compiled to, you may get distortion or clipping when the sound is played back. Note that the gain scale is linear, and to instantly change the gain, simply set the time argument to 0.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the sound to set the gain for.

Parameter.Name: volume
Parameter.Description: Value for the music volume.

Parameter.Name: time
Parameter.Description: The length for the change in gain in milliseconds.

Function.Name: audio_sound_gain

Function.Description: This function will return the current gain value for the given sound. The sound can either be one referenced from an index for an individual sound being played which has been stored in a variable when using the audio_play_sound() or audio_play_sound_at() functions, or an actual sound asset from the Asset Browser. Gain is usually calculated as a value from 0 to 1, but on some platforms you can have a gain of greater than 1, although a value of 1 is considered "full volume" and anything greater may introduce audio clipping.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the sound to get the gain of.

Function.Name: audio_sound_get_gain

Function.Description: This function will return the bit-mask data that defines which audio listeners a sound should be played from. See the section on Audio Listeners for more information.

Parameter.Name: soundid
Parameter.Description: The unique ID of the sound to get the mask of

Function.Name: audio_sound_get_listener_mask

Function.Description: This function can be used to get the get pitch of a given sound. The sound can either be one referenced from an index for an individual sound being played which has been stored in a variable when using the audio_play_sound() or audio_play_sound_at() functions, or an actual sound asset from the Asset Browser.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the sound to get the pitch of.

Function.Name: audio_sound_get_pitch

Function.Description: This function will get the position (in seconds) within the sound file for the sound to play from. The sound can only be a single instance of a sound (the index for individual sounds being played can be stored in a variable when using the audio_play_sound() or audio_play_sound_at() functions).

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the sound to get the play position of.

Function.Name: audio_sound_get_track_position

Function.Description: This function can be used to checks if the given sound index can be played currently. This is needed due to the different ways streamed and unstreamed sound playback is handled on the HTML5 target platform, and will return true if the sound can be played and false if it can't. Note that on all other platforms other than HTML5, the function will always return true..

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the sound to check.

Function.Name: audio_sound_is_playable

Function.Description: This function will return the length of the given sound in seconds. The sound can either be a referenced from index for an individual sound being played which has been stored in a variable when using the audio_play_sound() or audio_play_sound_at() functions, or an actual sound asset from the Asset Browser.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the sound to check.

Function.Name: audio_sound_length

Function.Description: This function can be used to change the pitch of a given sound. The sound can either be one referenced from an index for an individual sound being played which has been stored in a variable when using the audio_play_sound() or audio_play_sound_at() functions, or an actual sound asset from the Asset Browser. If it is an index of a playing sound, then only that instance will be changed, however when using a sound asset from the Asset Browser, all further instances being played of that sound will be changed.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the sound to change.

Parameter.Name: pitch
Parameter.Description: The pitch multiplier (default 1).

Function.Name: audio_sound_pitch

Function.Description: This function can be used to set the the bit-mask for a sound so that it will play only from those listeners specified. You can create a bit-mask by using the audio_get_listener_info() and then using the bitwise or ("|") to create a custom mask with those listeners that you require the sound to play from, and then apply this custom mask to the sound after you have played it. This mask will over-ride the default mask or that which you may have set using the function audio_set_listener_mask().

Parameter.Name: soundid
Parameter.Description: The unique ID of the sound to set the mask of

Parameter.Name: mask
Parameter.Description: The bitmask data to set for the sound

Function.Name: audio_sound_set_listener_mask

Function.Description: This function will set the position (in seconds) within the sound file for the sound to play from. The sound can either be a single instance of a sound (the index for individual sounds being played can be stored in a variable when using the audio_play_sound() or audio_play_sound_at() functions) or a sound asset. If it is a unique sound ID that you use, then the position will change immediately to the new time given, and if it is a Asset Browser asset then all further plays of the given sound will start at the new time. The function will ignore any value given that is longer than the length of the sound given for the "index" value.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the sound to change.

Parameter.Name: time
Parameter.Description: The time (in seconds) to set the start point to.

Function.Name: audio_sound_set_track_position

Function.Description: This function will set the state of a playing sound's loop section.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the sound to change.

Parameter.Name: state
Parameter.Description: The state that the loop section should be set to.

Function.Name: audio_sound_loop

Function.Description: This function will return the state of a playing sound's loop section.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the sound whose loop section state is retrieved.

Function.Name: audio_sound_get_loop

Function.Description: This function will set the offset (in seconds) of the start of a sound's loop section.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the sound to change.

Parameter.Name: time
Parameter.Description: The offset (in seconds) to set the start of the loop section to.

Function.Name: audio_sound_loop_start

Function.Description: This function will return the offset (in seconds) of the start of a sound's loop section.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the sound whose loop-start is retrieved.

Function.Name: audio_sound_get_loop_start

Function.Description: This function will set the offset (in seconds) of the end of a sound's loop section.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the sound to change.

Parameter.Name: time
Parameter.Description: The offset (in seconds) to set the end of the loop section to.

Function.Name: audio_sound_loop_end

Function.Description: This function will return the offset (in seconds) of the end of a sound's loop section.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the sound whose loop-end is retrieved.

Function.Name: audio_sound_get_loop_end

Function.Description: This function will stop all sounds that are currently playing.
Function.Name: audio_stop_all

Function.Description: This function will stop the given sound if it is currently playing. The sound can either be a single instance of a sound (the index for individual sounds being played can be stored in a variable when using the audio_play_sound() or audio_play_sound_at() functions) or a sound asset, in which case all instances of the given sound will be stopped.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the sound to stop.

Function.Name: audio_stop_sound

Function.Description: This function can be used to check and see if the audio system has been initialised, or if the audio context is running. On all platforms, this function will return true immediately after Game Start when the audio engine is initialised, except on the Opera GX and HTML5 targets. On Opera GX and HTML5, the audio context status can change at any time depending on user input, the browser being used, and its version, so this function can be used to check and see if audio can be played or not. If the function returns false (ie: the audio context status is not running), then only unstreamed sounds may play (but it's not guaranteed, and you should assume that no audio can be played), while if it returns true then all audio will play.
Function.Name: audio_system_is_available

Function.Description: This function can be used to check if the audio engine has been initialised, after which all audio functions can be called normally. For all targets other than HTML5, this will return true on Game Start. On HTML5, this may only begin to return true after Game Start. While audio_system_is_available() reflects the ability to play audio, this function reflects the ability to call audio functions more generally.
Function.Name: audio_system_is_initialised

Function.Description: With this function you can create a new sound from the contents of a buffer. The buffer will have been created previously (see the buffer functions for details on how to do this), and have had data added or loaded into it. You then pass it to this function with the data format (only buffer_u8 or buffer_s16 are currently supported), the sample rate (which can be between 1000hz and 48000hz), and an offset into the buffer to get the data from. You also need to supply the number of samples in the buffer and the channels that the sound requires. These channels are defined by one of the following constants:

Parameter.Name: bufferId
Parameter.Description: The ID of the buffer to use.

Parameter.Name: bufferFormat
Parameter.Description: The format of the data in the buffer (buffer_u8 or buffer_s16).

Parameter.Name: bufferRate
Parameter.Description: The sample rate of the data in the buffer.

Parameter.Name: bufferOffset
Parameter.Description: The offset into the buffer to read the sample data from (in bytes).

Parameter.Name: bufferLength
Parameter.Description: The length of the buffer (the number of bytes of audio data, excluding the header).

Parameter.Name: bufferChannels
Parameter.Description: The channels to use (audio_mono, audio_stereo or audio_3D).

Function.Name: audio_create_buffer_sound

Function.Description: This function prepares a buffer queue for audio. You pass data format (only buffer_u8 or buffer_s16 are currently supported), the sample rate (which can be between 1000hz and 48000hz), and the channels that the audio requires from one of the constants listed below:

Parameter.Name: queueformat
Parameter.Description: The format of the buffer data to use (buffer_u8 or buffer_s16).

Parameter.Name: queuerate
Parameter.Description: The sample rate of the data in the buffer queue.

Parameter.Name: queuechannels
Parameter.Description: The channels to use from one of the constants listed below.

Function.Name: audio_create_play_queue

Function.Description: With this function you can free up the pointer index value associated with the sound ID. Freed sounds will not be available for playing, and if multiple instances of the sound are being played they will all be stopped. Note that before you can delete the buffer itself, you must first free all sound ID's associated with it.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the buffered sound to free.

Function.Name: audio_free_buffer_sound

Function.Description: This function is used to free up the memory associated with the given audio queue. The queue index is the value returned when you created the queue using the function audio_create_play_queue(), and this function should be called when the queue is no longer required to prevent memory leaks. Freeing the queue will stop any sound that is be playing, and you cannot delete the buffer that a sound is being streamed from until the queue it is assigned to has been freed. This function will trigger an Audio Playback Asynchronous Event, and in this event a special DS map will be created in the variable async_load with the following key/value pairs:

Parameter.Name: queueindex
Parameter.Description: The index of the queue to free.

Function.Name: audio_free_play_queue

Function.Description: This function will return the number of audio recording sources (like microphones, etc...) currently available to your game. So, if you have a return value of, for example, four, then you will have audio input on the sources 0, 1, 2 and 3, with one of these values being that which you use to start recording from using the function audio_start_recording(). This value can change at any time as people plug/unplug microphones or other input sources to the device. Note that you can use the function audio_get_recorder_info() to get information on each device connected.
Function.Name: audio_get_recorder_count

Function.Description: This function will return a DS Map with information about the given recorder source index. You can find out how many recorder sources are available using the function audio_get_recorder_count(), and the map returned will contain the following key/value pairs:

Parameter.Name: recorder_index
Parameter.Description: The index of the recorder source to get the information from.

Function.Name: audio_get_recorder_info

Function.Description: This function will add the data from a buffer into the audio queue that you previously created using the function audio_create_play_queue(). You specify the queue index to add to, and the buffer ID to get the data from as well as the position (offset) within the buffer and the number of bytes to add. Once you have added audio from a buffer to a queue, the buffer cannot be deleted until you have first freed the queue using the function audio_free_play_queue(), and the buffer properties should match those of the the queue that you are adding the sound to.

Parameter.Name: queueindex
Parameter.Description: The index of the queue to add to.

Parameter.Name: bufferid
Parameter.Description: The buffer to add to the queue.

Parameter.Name: bufferoffset
Parameter.Description: The offset within the source buffer to start from.

Parameter.Name: bufferlength
Parameter.Description: The length of the buffer (the number of the bytes in the buffer).

Function.Name: audio_queue_sound

Function.Description: This function will start recording audio from the recorder source indexed. You can get the number of recorder sources using the function audio_get_recorder_count(), and once you start recording the audio will be stored in a temporary buffer and start triggering an Audio Recording Asynchronous Event. This event is triggered every step that recording takes place and will create the special DS map in the variable async_load with the following key/value pairs:

Parameter.Name: recorder_index
Parameter.Description: The index of the recorder source to use.

Function.Name: audio_start_recording

Function.Description: This function will stop recording on the given recorder channel (the channel index is returned when you call the function audio_start_recording()). When you stop recording, no further Audio Recording Asynchronous Events will be triggered for the given recorder channel, so you would normally use this function in the actual asynchronous event to ensure that you have captured all the data.

Parameter.Name: channel_index
Parameter.Description: The index of the recorder channel to stop.

Function.Name: audio_stop_recording

Function.Description: This function creates a new audio emitter and returns the index for it. This index should be stored in a variable for all further functions that relate to this emitter, and then when it is no longer needed it should be removed from memory using the function audio_emitter_free() to prevent memory leaks which may eventually crash your game.
Function.Name: audio_emitter_create

Function.Description: This function returns whether an audio emitter exists (true) or not (false). Note that if the index you search for has not been initialised previously, this function will cause an error as it is searching for non-existent indices.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the emitter to check the existence of.

Function.Name: audio_emitter_exists

Function.Description: With this function you can set the fall-off distance for an emitter. This is the distance from the listener the emitter has to be before the sound will have "fallen off" to a volume of 0. The default value for this is 100, but beware of setting this to any value lower than 1 as that will make any sound played through this emitter inaudible to the listener, however any other value will cause the sound to fade away the further that the emitter is from the listener.

Parameter.Name: emitter
Parameter.Description: The index of the emitter to change.

Parameter.Name: falloff_ref
Parameter.Description: The falloff reference relative to the listener (clamp).

Parameter.Name: falloff_max
Parameter.Description: The maximum falloff distance relative to the listener.

Parameter.Name: falloff_factor
Parameter.Description: The falloff factor (default 1).

Function.Name: audio_emitter_falloff

Function.Description: With this function you can remove the given emitter from memory. This should always be done whenever the emitter is not going to be used further in the room or the game, ie: in the Destroy Event of the instance or in the Room End Event, otherwise you may end up with a memory leak that will slow down and eventually crash your game.

Parameter.Name: emitter
Parameter.Description: The index of the emitter to free.

Function.Name: audio_emitter_free

Function.Description: This function sets the maximum gain (volume) for the sound. The perceived volume for a sound can change depending on the fall-off value and the position it has relative to the listener, but by setting the gain with this function, the full volume will never exceed the specified gain value. The image below illustrates how gain affects the volume of the emitter when fall-off is greater than 0:

Parameter.Name: emitter
Parameter.Description: The index of the emitter to change.

Parameter.Name: gain
Parameter.Description: The maximum gain (default 1).

Function.Name: audio_emitter_gain

Function.Description: This function returns the current gain (volume) set for the given audio emitter, normally between 0 and 1, where 0 is silent and 1 is full volume. Note that on some platforms you can have a gain of greater than 1, although a value of 1 is considered "full volume" and anything greater may introduce audio clipping.

Parameter.Name: emitter
Parameter.Description: The index of the emitter to use.

Function.Name: audio_emitter_get_gain

Function.Description: This function will return the bit-mask data that defines which audio listeners an emitter should play sounds from. For more information see the section on Audio Listeners.

Parameter.Name: emitterid
Parameter.Description: The unique ID of the emitter to get the mask of

Function.Name: audio_emitter_get_listener_mask

Function.Description: This function returns the current pitch value set for the given audio emitter.

Parameter.Name: emitter
Parameter.Description: The index of the emitter to use.

Function.Name: audio_emitter_get_pitch

Function.Description: This function returns the current velocity along the x axis for the given audio emitter.

Parameter.Name: emitter
Parameter.Description: The index of the emitter to use.

Function.Name: audio_emitter_get_vx

Function.Description: This function returns the current velocity along the y axis for the given audio emitter.

Parameter.Name: emitter
Parameter.Description: The index of the emitter to use.

Function.Name: audio_emitter_get_vy

Function.Description: This function returns the current velocity along the z axis for the given audio emitter.

Parameter.Name: emitter
Parameter.Description: The index of the emitter to use.

Function.Name: audio_emitter_get_vz

Function.Description: This function returns the current x position of the given audio emitter.

Parameter.Name: emitter
Parameter.Description: The index of the emitter to use.

Function.Name: audio_emitter_get_x

Function.Description: This function returns the current y position of the given audio emitter.

Parameter.Name: emitter
Parameter.Description: The index of the emitter to use.

Function.Name: audio_emitter_get_y

Function.Description: This function returns the current z position of the given audio emitter.

Parameter.Name: emitter
Parameter.Description: The index of the emitter to use.

Function.Name: audio_emitter_get_z

Function.Description: This function can be used to change the pitch of all sounds emitted from the given emitter. It is a pitch multiplier, in that the input value multiplies the current pitch by that amount, so the default value of 1 is no pitch change, while a value of less than 1 will lower the pitch and greater than 1 will raise the pitch. It is best to use small increments for this function as any value under 0 or over 5 may not be audible anyway.

Parameter.Name: emitter
Parameter.Description: The index of the emitter to change.

Parameter.Name: pitch
Parameter.Description: The pitch multiplier (default 1).

Function.Name: audio_emitter_pitch

Function.Description: With this function you can change the position of an audio emitter within the 3D audio space. The position will affect the sound in different ways depending on where the listener is positioned within the audio space too (default position is (0, 0, 0). See audio_listener_position() for more information), so for example if the emitter position is set to (100, 0, 0) and the current listener is at (200, 0, 0) the audio streamed from the emitter will appear to be on the left of the audio field. The image below shows a visual representation of emitters and their relative positions to the listener:

Parameter.Name: emitter
Parameter.Description: The index of the emitter to change.

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x position.

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y position.

Parameter.Name: z
Parameter.Description: The z position.

Function.Name: audio_emitter_position

Function.Description: This function can be used to set the the bit-mask for an emitter so that all sounds played through the emitter will play only from those listeners specified. You can create a bit-mask by using the audio_get_listener_info() and then using the bitwise or ("|") to create a custom mask with those listeners that you require the sound to play from, and then apply this custom mask to the emitter. This mask will over-ride the default mask or that which you may have set using the function audio_set_listener_mask().

Parameter.Name: emitterid
Parameter.Description: The unique ID of the emitter to set the mask of

Parameter.Name: mask
Parameter.Description: The bitmask data to set for the sound

Function.Name: audio_emitter_set_listener_mask

Function.Description: This function can be used to give an emitter Doppler effects and simulate audio motion based on the vector that is resolved from the given relative x, y and z positions. If the emitter itself is not ever going to move you would normally not need to set these values, but, for example, if you are making a scrolling shooter game where the enemies come from the right and scroll to the left, you would set this to have a velocity of (hspeed, 0, 0) in the create event of the enemies (and update the emitter of each instance in the step event using audio_emitter_position()) to give any sounds emitted by the enemy instances the correct Doppler as they pass the player instance (which in turn would be using the function audio_listener_position() to set the listener to the correct position).

Parameter.Name: emitter
Parameter.Description: The index of the emitter to change.

Parameter.Name: vx
Parameter.Description: The x vector value (default 0).

Parameter.Name: vy
Parameter.Description: The y vector value (default 0).

Parameter.Name: vz
Parameter.Description: The z vector value (default 0).

Function.Name: audio_emitter_velocity

Function.Description: With this function you can play any sound resource through an emitter, with any changes to the emitter gain, position, pitch or velocity affecting how the user hears the final sound being played. You provide the emitter index to use, the sound index of the sound to be played and then specify whether the sound is to loop or not. Finally you can assign a priority, which is then used to determine how sounds are dealt with when the number of sounds playing is over the limit set by the function audio_channel_num(). Lower priority sounds will be stopped in favour of higher priority sounds, and the priority value can be any real number (the actual value is arbitrary, and can be from 0 to 1 or 0 to 100, as GameMaker will prioritize them the same). Note that when dealing with priority, the higher the number the higher the priority, such that a sound with priority 100 will be favoured over a sound with priority 1.

Parameter.Name: emitter
Parameter.Description: The index of the emitter to use.

Parameter.Name: sound
Parameter.Description: The index of the sound to use.

Parameter.Name: loop
Parameter.Description: Flags the sound as looping or not.

Parameter.Name: priority
Parameter.Description: Set the channel priority for the sound.

Parameter.Name: gain
Parameter.Description: Sets the gain of the sound played.

Parameter.Name: offset
Parameter.Description: Sets the start offset (in seconds) of the sound played.

Parameter.Name: pitch
Parameter.Description: Sets the pitch of the sound played.

Parameter.Name: listener_mask
Parameter.Description: Sets the listener mask of the sound played.

Function.Name: audio_play_sound_on

Function.Description: This function will check a specific audio group to see if it has been loaded into memory, ready for use.

Parameter.Name: groupid
Parameter.Description: The index of the audio group to check (as defined in the Audio Groups Window)

Function.Name: audio_group_is_loaded

Function.Description: This function will load all the sounds that are flagged as belonging to the given Audio Group into memory. The function will return true if loading is initiated and false if the group ID is invalid, or it has already been flagged for loading. The function is asynchronous so your game will continue to run while the audio is loaded in the background. This means that it will also trigger an Asynchronous Load/Save Event to inform you that the whole group has been loaded into memory and the sounds can now be used.

Parameter.Name: groupid
Parameter.Description: The index of the audio group to load (as defined in the Audio Groups Window)

Function.Name: audio_group_load

Function.Description: This function will check the loading progress for an audio group and return an (approximate) value between 0 and 100.

Parameter.Name: groupid
Parameter.Description: The index of the audio group to check (as defined in the Audio Groups Window)

Function.Name: audio_group_load_progress

Function.Description: This function will return a string containing the name of the given audio group for displaying or checking. When you define an audio group in the Game Options, you give it a unique "name" which is really a constant to use as an ID value for the group. All this function does is take the ID and return a string of the ID name you gave.

Parameter.Name: groupid
Parameter.Description: The index value constant of the audio group to check (as defined in the Audio Groups Window)

Function.Name: audio_group_name

Function.Description: With this function you can fade a group of sounds in or out over a given length of time, or it can be used to set the group gain instantly. The time is measured in milliseconds, and the function requires that you input a final level of gain for the group to have reached by the end of that time. This gain can be between 0 (silent) and 1 (full volume) and the scale is linear, such that a value of 0.5 would be half volume. To instantly change the gain, simply set the time argument to 0. Note that on some platforms you can have a gain of greater than 1, although a value of 1 is considered "full volume" and anything greater may introduce audio clipping.

Parameter.Name: groupid
Parameter.Description: The index of the audio group to stop (as defined in the Audio Groups Window)

Parameter.Name: volume
Parameter.Description: The final value for the group volume.

Parameter.Name: time
Parameter.Description: The length of the change in gain in milliseconds.

Function.Name: audio_group_set_gain

Function.Description: This function will return the group gain of a given audio group.

Parameter.Name: groupid
Parameter.Description: The index of the audio group to check (as defined in the Audio Groups window)

Function.Name: audio_group_get_gain

Function.Description: This function will stop all sounds from the given audio group that are currently playing.

Parameter.Name: groupid
Parameter.Description: The index of the audio group to stop (as defined in the Audio Groups Window)

Function.Name: audio_group_stop_all

Function.Description: This function will unload all the sounds that are flagged as belonging to the given Audio Group into memory. The function will return true if unloading is initiated and false if the group ID is invalid, or it has already been flagged for unloading. Note that any audio currently being played when this function is called will be stopped.

Parameter.Name: groupid
Parameter.Description: The index of the audio group to unload (as defined in the Audio Groups Window)

Function.Name: audio_group_unload

Function.Description: This function will return an array containing the asset index of each audio asset in the given audio group.

Parameter.Name: group_index
Parameter.Description: The index of the audio group whose asset indices should be retrieved.

Function.Name: audio_group_get_assets

Function.Description: This function will return the index of the audio group that is associated with the given sound index.

Parameter.Name: sound_index
Parameter.Description: The index of the sound whose audio group should be retrieved.

Function.Name: audio_sound_get_audio_group

Function.Description: Certain target platforms permit more than one listener, so it is important that you know how many the target has before changing or using different listeners. This function will return the number of listeners available.
Function.Name: audio_get_listener_count

Function.Description: This function will create a DS map and populate it with information for the given listener.

Parameter.Name: num
Parameter.Description: The listener number to get the data for.

Function.Name: audio_get_listener_info

Function.Description: This function will return the bit-mask data that defines the current default (global) mask for the audio listeners.
Function.Name: audio_get_listener_mask

Function.Description: This function will create a DS map and populate it with the position, velocity and orientation values for the given listener. The default listener index is 0, but you can use the function audio_get_listener_info() to get the different indices available for the target platform. If you provide an incorrect listener index then the function will return -1.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The listener to get the data for (default 0).

Function.Name: audio_listener_get_data

Function.Description: With this function you can change the orientation of the listener within the 3D audio space. The look at direction and up direction are based on the vectors that are resolved from the given relative x, y and z positions, and default to (0, 0, 1000) for the look at direction and (0, 1, 0) for the up direction, as shown in the illustration below:

Parameter.Name: lookat_x
Parameter.Description: The x look vector (default 0).

Parameter.Name: lookat_y
Parameter.Description: The y look vector (default 0).

Parameter.Name: lookat_z
Parameter.Description: The z look vector (default 1000).

Parameter.Name: up_x
Parameter.Description: The x up vector (default 0).

Parameter.Name: up_y
Parameter.Description: The y up vector (default 1).

Parameter.Name: up_z
Parameter.Description: The z up vector (default 0).

Function.Name: audio_listener_orientation

Function.Description: With this function you can change the position of the listener within the 3D audio space. The example image below shows the default position for the listener in the audio space:

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x position of the listener (default 0).

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y position of the listener (default 0).

Parameter.Name: z
Parameter.Description: The z position of the listener (default 0).

Function.Name: audio_listener_position

Function.Description: With this function you can change the orientation of the given listener within the 3D audio space. The default listener index is 0, but you can use the function audio_get_listener_info() to get the different indices available for the target platform.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The listener to set the orientation of.

Parameter.Name: lookat_x
Parameter.Description: The x look vector (default 0).

Parameter.Name: lookat_y
Parameter.Description: The y look vector (default 0).

Parameter.Name: lookat_z
Parameter.Description: The z look vector (default -1).

Parameter.Name: up_x
Parameter.Description: The x up vector (default 0).

Parameter.Name: up_y
Parameter.Description: The y up vector (default 1).

Parameter.Name: up_z
Parameter.Description: The z up vector (default 0).

Function.Name: audio_listener_set_orientation

Function.Description: With this function you can change the position of a given listener within the 3D audio space. The default listener index is 0, but you can use the function audio_get_listener_info() to get the different indices available for the target platform. The example image below shows the default position for the listener in the audio space:

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The listener to get the data for (default 0).

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x position of the listener (default 0).

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y position of the listener (default 0).

Parameter.Name: z
Parameter.Description: The z position of the listener (default 0).

Function.Name: audio_listener_set_position

Function.Description: This function can be used to give the given listener Doppler effects and simulate audio motion based on the vector that is resolved from the given relative x, y and z positions. The default listener index is 0, but you can use the function audio_get_listener_info() to get the different indices available for the target platform.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The listener to get the data for (default 0).

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x velocity of the listener (default 0).

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y velocity of the listener (default 0).

Parameter.Name: z
Parameter.Description: The z velocity of the listener (default 0).

Function.Name: audio_listener_set_velocity

Function.Description: This function can be used to give the listener Doppler effects and simulate audio motion based on the vector that is resolved from the given relative x, y and z positions. If the listener itself is not ever going to move, or the movement is not a constant motion, you would normally not need to set these values, but, for example, if you are making a scrolling game where the player has a constant bottom to top movement and the enemies a constant top to bottom movement, you would set the listener and emitter velocities (for emitters you would use audio_emitter_velocity()) to the appropriate vectors to simulate the correct Doppler effect as they move past the player instance.

Parameter.Name: vx
Parameter.Description: The x velocity component of the listener (default 0).

Parameter.Name: vy
Parameter.Description: The y velocity component of the listener (default 0).

Parameter.Name: vz
Parameter.Description: The z velocity component of the listener (default 0).

Function.Name: audio_listener_velocity

Function.Description: When using multiple listeners on a system, you can set the bit-mask for a sound and have it heard from the flagged listener only. However, you can also set the global mask using this function and all sounds played normally will be heard from the listeners flagged by this mask, without the need to set the mask for each sound individually.

Parameter.Name: mask
Parameter.Description: The bit-mask data to set for the listeners

Function.Name: audio_set_listener_mask

Function.Description: Creates a sync group and returns a unique ID value for it which should then be used in all further audio function calls for this group. If you want the group to loop then pass in true, otherwise pass in false, but note that if you want them to loop, all the tracks added later need to be the same length. Note that when you create a sync group, you will need to free the memory and sounds associated with it when not in use using the audio_destroy_sync_group() function - for example, in the Room End or Destroy events.

Parameter.Name: loop
Parameter.Description: Whether the tracks in the group should loop (true) or not (false).

Function.Name: audio_create_sync_group

Function.Description: Audio sync groups need to be destroyed when not in use to free up the memory and sound resources associated with them using this function. It takes the group index as returned when the group was created using the function audio_create_sync_group(), and frees all resources used by the group.

Parameter.Name: group_index
Parameter.Description: The group index to be destroyed.

Function.Name: audio_destroy_sync_group

Function.Description: his function will pause the given sync group if it is playing, with the group index being the value returned when you created the group using the function audio_create_sync_group(). This does not stop the sound, and calling audio_resume_sync_group(), will start it playing from the same position it was paused at again.

Parameter.Name: group_index
Parameter.Description: The group index to pause.

Function.Name: audio_pause_sync_group

Function.Description: With this function you can assign a sound to a previously create sync group. The group index is the value returned when you created the group using the function audio_create_sync_group(), and the sound index is the index of any compressed sound (*.ogg or *.mp3) from the Asset Browser. This function only adds the sound to the group, but it does not play the sound, and will be a value > -1 if it succeeds and -1 if it fails, where a successful value indicates the sounds order in the sync group (so 0 would be the first sound added, 1 would be the second, etc...).

Parameter.Name: group_index
Parameter.Description: The group index to assign the sound to.

Parameter.Name: sound_index
Parameter.Description: The sound index to be assigned to the group.

Function.Name: audio_play_in_sync_group

Function.Description: This function will resume the given sync group if it is playing and has previously been paused (using the function audio_pause_sync_group). The group index is the value returned when you created the group using the function audio_create_sync_group().

Parameter.Name: group_index
Parameter.Description: The group index to resume.

Function.Name: audio_resume_sync_group

Function.Description: With this function you can start playing a previously created sync group. You need to supply the group index which is the value returned when you created the group using the function audio_create_sync_group().

Parameter.Name: group_index
Parameter.Description: The group index to play.

Function.Name: audio_start_sync_group

Function.Description: This function will stop the given sync group if it is playing, with the group index being the value returned when you created the group using the function audio_create_sync_group().

Parameter.Name: group_index
Parameter.Description: The group index to stop playing.

Function.Name: audio_stop_sync_group

Function.Description: his function can be used to display debug information about any given sync group (the group index is the value returned when the group was created using the function audio_create_sync_group()). You can call the function with a value of -1 to switch off the overlay.

Parameter.Name: group_index
Parameter.Description: The group index to debug, or -1 to switch off the debugging.

Function.Name: audio_sync_group_debug

Function.Description: This function returns the current play position of the given sync group. The group index is the value returned when you created the group using the function audio_create_sync_group(), and the return value is the time in seconds that the tracks have been playing.

Parameter.Name: group_index
Parameter.Description: The group index to get the position of.

Function.Name: audio_sync_group_get_track_pos

Function.Description: This function can be used to check if any audio in a synchronised group is playing. You are required to supply the sync group ID as returned by the function audio_create_sync_group().

Parameter.Name: group_index
Parameter.Description: The group index to check.

Function.Name: audio_sync_group_is_playing

Function.Description: This function can be used to check if any audio in a synchronised group is paused. You are required to supply the sync group ID as returned by the function audio_create_sync_group().

Parameter.Name: group_index
Parameter.Description: The group index to check.

Function.Name: audio_sync_group_is_paused

Function.Description: This function creates and returns a new audio bus struct, which can be modified to configure the bus' properties and to add audio effects to it.
Function.Name: audio_bus_create

Function.Description: This function creates and returns a new audio effect struct, which can be modified to configure the effect's properties.

Parameter.Name: type
Parameter.Description: The type of audio effect to create.

Parameter.Name: params
Parameter.Description: A struct containing any initial values for the effect's parameters.

Function.Name: audio_effect_create

Function.Description: This function links an emitter to an audio bus. Any sounds played on this emitter will be processed by the audio bus.

Parameter.Name: emitter
Parameter.Description: The emitter to link to the audio bus.

Parameter.Name: bus
Parameter.Description: The audio bus to link the emitter to.

Function.Name: audio_emitter_bus

Function.Description: This function returns the audio bus that an emitter is linked to.

Parameter.Name: emitter
Parameter.Description: The emitter whose audio bus should be returned.

Function.Name: audio_emitter_get_bus

Function.Description: This function returns an array of all of the audio emitters linked to a given audio bus.

Parameter.Name: bus
Parameter.Description: The audio bus whose emitters should be returned.

Function.Name: audio_bus_get_emitters

Function.Description: This function relinks all of the emitters linked to the given bus back to the main bus.

Parameter.Name: bus
Parameter.Description: The audio bus whose emitters should be cleared.

Function.Name: audio_bus_clear_emitters

Function.Description: Converts a linear gain to a gain in decibels (dB).

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The value to convert.

Function.Name: lin_to_db

Function.Description: Converts a gain in decibels (dB) to a linear gain.

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The value to convert.

Function.Name: db_to_lin

Function.Description: This function can be used to add a font to your game from a font file present in the Included Files. You can define the size of the font (in points), as well as whether the font should be bold or italic, and you can also define the range of characters to include. The function returns an index value that should be stored in a variable as this will be needed in all further code that refer to this font, or it will return -1 if the function fails for any reason.

Parameter.Name: name
Parameter.Description: The path of the font file in the Included Files (*.ttf or *.otf).

Parameter.Name: size
Parameter.Description: The size of the font - points for Web Fonts, pixels for file fonts.

Parameter.Name: bold
Parameter.Description: Whether the font is bold (true) or not (false).

Parameter.Name: italic
Parameter.Description: Whether the font is italic (true) or not (false).

Parameter.Name: first
Parameter.Description: The first character to include (if you're unsure, go for 32).

Parameter.Name: last
Parameter.Description: The last character to include (if you're unsure, go for 128).

Function.Name: font_add

Function.Description: This function can be used to enable or disable anti-aliasing (AA) for fonts added using font_add(). This function needs to be called before you add any fonts and setting it to true will enable AA, and setting it to false will disable it. By default AA is enabled. Note that this will have no effect on fonts that have been added before the function was called, and the function only needs to be called once when the font is added, and not every draw/step that the font is being used.

Parameter.Name: enable
Parameter.Description: Whether to enable (true) or disable (false) AA for added fonts.

Function.Name: font_add_enable_aa

Function.Description: This function can be used to check whether anti-aliasing (AA) is enabled for fonts added using font_add(). The function will return true if AA is enabled, and false if it is not. Note that AA is enabled by default, but you can change the AA state for added fonts using the function font_add_enable_aa(), as long as it is called before adding the font.
Function.Name: font_add_get_enable_aa

Function.Description: With this function you can use a "sprite strip" to create a new font asset, where each sub-image would be an individual symbol or letter. The index is the UTF8 map number for the first character to use and the ranges to use are the same as you would for a normal font, starting with "!" but remember that you should only include what you need and that you should be using the ord() function to get the correct UTF8 value for the starting letter. The created sprite font will then have the sub-images set to an individual glyph from the font, where the "first" glyph will have the image_index of 0. You can define "space" as being any character you want, for example a single line the size that you want the space to be, and all spaces in text will be rendered at that width (but the image chosen will never be rendered), or if you don't supply a sprite for space then the width of the widest character in the sprite font will be used instead.

Parameter.Name: spr
Parameter.Description: The sprite to add a font based on.

Parameter.Name: first
Parameter.Description: The index of the first available character.

Parameter.Name: prop
Parameter.Description: Set as proportional font or not.

Parameter.Name: sep
Parameter.Description: The space to leave between each letter.

Function.Name: font_add_sprite

Function.Description: With this function you can use a "sprite strip" (the sprite itself must be a sprite asset from the Asset Browser, or a sprite you have added to the game resources using sprite_add) to create a new font asset, where each sub-image would be an individual symbol or letter. Unlike the normal font_add_sprite() which has a specific order for the sub-images of the sprite, this function will map the sprite sub-images based on the argument "string_map" of the function. This argument is a string that you can use to tell GameMaker what order the sub-images of the sprite font are and it will map these automatically when writing text. So, for example, if you have a string-map of "AaBbCcDdEeFfGgHh", your sprite font must have the sub-images ordered in this way. You can define "space" as being any character you want, for example a single line the size that you want the space to be, and all spaces in text will be rendered at that width (but the image chosen will never be rendered), or if you don't supply a sprite for space then the width of the widest character in the sprite font will be used instead.

Parameter.Name: spr
Parameter.Description: The sprite to add a font based on.

Parameter.Name: string_map
Parameter.Description: String from which sprite sub-image order is taken.

Parameter.Name: prop
Parameter.Description: Set as proportional font or not.

Parameter.Name: sep
Parameter.Description: The space to leave between each letter.

Function.Name: font_add_sprite_ext

Function.Description: With this function you can delete a font asset from the game. This is a permanent removal, and changing rooms, or restarting the game will not bring the removed font back. For that the player would need to exit the game and restart that way, so take care when using this function. In general it is only needed for freeing up memory that has been used by a font added to the game through the functions font_add() or font_add_sprite().

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the font to delete.

Function.Name: font_delete

Function.Description: With this function you can enable or disable SDF rendering for the specified font. This only works on fonts added using font_add().

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the font.

Parameter.Name: enable
Parameter.Description: Whether to enable (true) or disable (false) SDF rendering for the specified font.

Function.Name: font_enable_sdf

Function.Description: With this function you can determine whether SDF rendering is enabled or disabled for the specified font

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the font.

Function.Name: font_get_sdf_enabled

Function.Description: With this function you can set the SDF spread value for the specified font. This only works on fonts added using font_add(), and its effect is only visible if the font is using SDF rendering.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the font.

Parameter.Name: spread
Parameter.Description: The SDF spread value to set for the specified font.

Function.Name: font_sdf_spread

Function.Description: With this function you can query the SDF spread value for the specified font

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the font.

Function.Name: font_get_sdf_spread

Function.Description: With this function you can enable or disable built-in effects rendering for the specified font. Built-in effects will only have an effect with SDF-enabled fonts.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the font.

Parameter.Name: enable
Parameter.Description: Whether to enable (true) or disable (false) effects rendering for the specified font.

Parameter.Name: params
Parameter.Description: A struct containing any initial values for the font's effect parameters.

Function.Name: font_enable_effects

Function.Description: This function returns whether a font with the specified index exists or not. You can check font indices as defined from the Asset Browser, or fonts that have been added using functions like font_add().

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: Index of the font to check.

Function.Name: font_exists

Function.Description: With this function you can check any font asset to see if it has the bold flag or not. If it does the function will return true, otherwise it will return false.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: Index of the font to check.

Function.Name: font_get_bold

Function.Description: With this function you can get the actual system name of the selected font asset. This function returns a string and not an index, and the name returned will depend on the font being used. For example, you may have a font asset called "fnt_Main" in the GameMaker Asset Browser, and the font itself may be the Windows system font Arial. In this case the function will return "Arial" as that is the system name of the font. Should you need the name as it appears in the Asset Browser, you should use font_get_name().

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: Index of the font to check.

Function.Name: font_get_fontname

Function.Description: This function is used to retrieve information for the given font. You supply a font index (which can be an asset added through the Asset Browser or a font added at runtime) and the function returns a struct with the following variables:

Parameter.Name: font
Parameter.Description: The font for which information should be retrieved.

Function.Name: font_get_info

Function.Description: With this function you can check any font asset to see if it has the italic flag or not. If it does the function will return true, otherwise it will return false.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: Index of the font to check.

Function.Name: font_get_italic

Function.Description: When defining a font in GameMaker, you can define a range of characters to include. This is because the font itself is not actually included with your game (for legal reasons) but an image of the font is included on a texture page and that is what your game will use (just like any other graphics asset). This means that you will want to keep the number of characters that you use to a minimum and specify only the range of characters that your game will need so as to keep texture memory as optimised as possible. This function can be used to find the last character (as an UTF8 value) that was used when your font asset was added to your game.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: Index of the font to check.

Function.Name: font_get_last

Function.Description: This function can be used to get the name (as a string) that was given to the font when it was added as an asset to the GameMaker Asset Browser. Please note that this is only a string and cannot be used to reference the font directly - for that you would need the font index. You can, however, use this string to get the font index using the returned string along with the function asset_get_index().

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: Index of the font to check.

Function.Name: font_get_name

Function.Description: With this function you can get the size of any font resource, which is the point value shown by the font resource dialogue.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: Index of the font to get the size of.

Function.Name: font_get_size

Function.Description: This function returns a special pointer for the font texture page. This value can then be used in other draw functions, particularly in general drawing when using primitives as well as the Shader functions. You can get more information about the returned texture page using the different texture_ functions found here.

Parameter.Name: font
Parameter.Description: The index of the font to use.

Function.Name: font_get_texture

Function.Description: This function returns an array with the UV coordinates for the font texture on the texture page, filling in the array with the following values:

Parameter.Name: font
Parameter.Description: The index of the font to use.

Function.Name: font_get_uvs

Function.Description: With this function you can use a "sprite strip" to replace a previously created sprite font asset, where each sub-image would be an individual symbol or letter. The index is the UTF8 map number for the first character to use and the ranges to use are the same as you would for a normal font, starting with "!" but remember that you should only include what you need and that you should be using the ord() function to get the correct UTF8 value for the starting letter.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the font that shall be replaced (ie all references to this resource past this function will refer to the new font, not the original).

Parameter.Name: spr
Parameter.Description: The sprite to add a font based on.

Parameter.Name: first
Parameter.Description: The index of the first available character.

Parameter.Name: prop
Parameter.Description: Whether white space around each letter should be removed (if false, the created font will be monospaced, otherwise it'll be like most regular fonts).

Parameter.Name: sep
Parameter.Description: The space between each letter, 0 meaning the right of one letter just touches the left of the next one.

Function.Name: font_replace_sprite

Function.Description: This function will replace a sprite font that you created previously using the function font_add_sprite_ext(). It uses a "sprite strip", where each sub-image is be an individual symbol or letter, and the images are mapped to letters based on the argument "string_map" of the function. This argument is a string that you can use to tell GameMaker what order the sub-images of the sprite font are and it will map these automatically when writing text.
