Parameter.Description: The new alpha of the particle system (from 0 to 1 where 0 is transparent and 1 opaque).

Function.Name: part_system_color

Function.Description: This function can be used to change colour and alpha with which the particle system is blended.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle system to change the colour and alpha of.

Parameter.Name: colour
Parameter.Description: The new colour with which to blend the particle system. c_white is to display it normally.

Parameter.Name: alpha
Parameter.Description: The new alpha of the particle system (from 0 to 1 where 0 is transparent and 1 opaque).

Function.Name: part_system_colour

Function.Description: With this function you can set the base position for the particle system relative to the (0,0) position of the room, meaning that all further particle functions relating to this system will now be drawn relative to the new position. By default this position is always (0,0), but in some very special circumstances you may wish to change this to something else.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle system to change.

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The new x coordinate of the particle system.

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The new y coordinate of the particle system.

Function.Name: part_system_position

Function.Description: This function can be used to change the rotation of the particle system.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle system to change the rotation of.

Parameter.Name: angle
Parameter.Description: The new rotation of the particle system in degrees.

Function.Name: part_system_angle

Function.Description: This function is used to set a particle type to have a single alpha value (transparency) for the total duration of the lifetime of each individual particle, and this can be from 0 (transparent) to 1 (opaque).

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to change.

Parameter.Name: alpha1
Parameter.Description: The alpha of the particle.

Function.Name: part_type_alpha1

Function.Description: This function can be used to set an alpha value (transparency) gradient for each particle created of the given type. The first alpha is that which all particles will start with, and the second alpha is the one on with which the particle will end with, and a smooth gradient change will occur to the alpha over the particles lifetime from one to the other. This can be from 0 (transparent) to 1 (opaque).

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to change.

Parameter.Name: alpha1
Parameter.Description: The start alpha of the particle.

Parameter.Name: alpha2
Parameter.Description: The end alpha of the particle.

Function.Name: part_type_alpha2

Function.Description: This function can be used to set a three alpha (transparency) value gradient for each particle created of the given type. The first alpha is that which all particles will start with, and the second alpha is the one that will be blended to half way through its lifetime and the third alpha is the one with which the particle will end with. A smooth gradient change will occur through the alphas over the particles lifetime from one to the other.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to change.

Parameter.Name: alpha1
Parameter.Description: The starting alpha of the particle.

Parameter.Name: alpha2
Parameter.Description: The halfway point alpha of the particle.

Parameter.Name: alpha3
Parameter.Description: The ending alpha of the particle.

Function.Name: part_type_alpha3

Function.Description: With this function you can make your particles be drawn with an additive blend mode (true) or not (false). Additive blending is a special blend mode that adds the luminosity values of each particle as they overlap, so that light colours will gradually get brighter (until they appear white) as they overlap, and dark colours become more and more transparent with black being almost invisible. This function can give some beautiful particle effects but may not always be necessary. For example, a smoke trail would have additive blending off to keep the effect gray, but a flame effect would probably have it on to make the particles more translucent and brighter.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to change.

Parameter.Name: additive
Parameter.Description: Whether the particles should be blended additively (true) or normally (false).

Function.Name: part_type_blend

Function.Description: With this function you can "reset" a particle, returning all the values for each of the functions relating to the particle (life, colour, alpha, orientation etc...) to their default values. Note that this function does not remove any particles currently visible in the room from the screen, for that you should be using part_particles_clear().

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to clear.

Function.Name: part_type_clear

Function.Description: This function is used to set a particle type to be a single colour for the total duration of the lifetime of each individual particle.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to change.

Parameter.Name: colour1
Parameter.Description: The single colour to make the particle type.

Function.Name: part_type_colour1

Function.Description: This function can be used to set a two colour gradient for each particle created of the given type. The first colour is that which all particles will start with, and the second colour is the one on which the particle will end with, and a smooth gradient change will occur to the colour over the particles lifetime from one colour to the other.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to change.

Parameter.Name: colour1
Parameter.Description: The colour the particle will start at.

Parameter.Name: colour2
Parameter.Description: The colour the particle will end at.

Function.Name: part_type_colour2

Function.Description: This function can be used to set a three colour gradient for each particle created of the given type. The first colour is that which all particles will start with, and the second colour is the one that will be blended to half way through its lifetime and the third colour is the one with which the particle will end with. A smooth gradient change will occur through the colours over the particles lifetime from one colour to the other.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to change.

Parameter.Name: colour1
Parameter.Description: The colour the particle will start at.

Parameter.Name: colour2
Parameter.Description: The colour the particle will be halfway through its lifespan.

Parameter.Name: colour3
Parameter.Description: The colour the particle will end at.

Function.Name: part_type_colour3

Function.Description: With this function you can set a hue, saturation and value range for all particles of the given type. You supply a minimum value and a maximum value for each of the three components and the particles created will have a random colour based on the given range of parameters. In this way you can create particles of the same hue but different saturations, or of different hues but the same value (luminosity) etc... All values must be between 0 and 255.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to change.

Parameter.Name: hmin
Parameter.Description: The minimum the final colour's hue component can be.

Parameter.Name: hmax
Parameter.Description: The maximum the final colour's hue component can be.

Parameter.Name: smin
Parameter.Description: The minimum the final colour's saturation component can be.

Parameter.Name: smax
Parameter.Description: The maximum the final colour's saturation component can be.

Parameter.Name: vmin
Parameter.Description: The minimum the final colour's value component can be.

Parameter.Name: vmax
Parameter.Description: The maximum the final colour's value component can be.

Function.Name: part_type_colour_hsv

Function.Description: With this function you can set the given particle type to be a random blend of two colours.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to change.

Parameter.Name: colour1
Parameter.Description: The first colour the blend will take from.

Parameter.Name: colour2
Parameter.Description: The second colour the blend will take from.

Function.Name: part_type_colour_mix

Function.Description: With this function you can set the mix of red, green and blue colours for all particles created of the given type. You supply a minimum value and a maximum value for each of the three components and the particles created will have a random colour based on the given range of parameters. All values must be between 0 and 255.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to change.

Parameter.Name: rmin
Parameter.Description: The minimum the final colour's red component can be.

Parameter.Name: rmax
Parameter.Description: The maximum the final colour's red component can be.

Parameter.Name: gmin
Parameter.Description: The minimum the final colour's green component can be.

Parameter.Name: gmax
Parameter.Description: The maximum the final colour's green component can be.

Parameter.Name: bmin
Parameter.Description: The minimum the final colour's blue component can be.

Parameter.Name: bmax
Parameter.Description: The maximum the final colour's blue component can be.

Function.Name: part_type_colour_rgb

Function.Description: With this function you can create a new particle type and the return value should be stored in a variable for use in all subsequent particle functions.
Function.Name: part_type_create

Function.Description: This function can be used to make your particle burst another type of particle at the end of its lifetime.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to change.

Parameter.Name: death_number
Parameter.Description: The quantity of the new particle to create at the particle death. If a negative value, it will instead create a fraction chance one is created (eg -3 would mean that one is created every 3 or so steps).

Parameter.Name: death_type
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to create.

Function.Name: part_type_death

Function.Description: With this function you can remove the specified particle type from the game. When you use this function, all particles of the given type will disappear from the room and the particle itself is removed form memory, so this function should be used only when you no longer need the particle.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to destroy.

Function.Name: part_type_destroy

Function.Description: This function is used to determine the direction of the particle when it is created and can also be used to make the particle increase or decrease its direction over its lifetime. The minimum and maximum direction values default at 0, which means that the particle will move to the right with no variation, but these values can be changed to limit the direction of movement following the standard GameMaker directions of 0 being right, 90 being up, 180 being left and 270 being down. If you set them to the same value the particles will only move in one direction.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to change.

Parameter.Name: dir_min
Parameter.Description: The minimum direction the particle can start at.

Parameter.Name: dir_max
Parameter.Description: The maximum direction the particle can start at.

Parameter.Name: dir_incr
Parameter.Description: How much the particle direction should increase or decrease per step.

Parameter.Name: dir_wiggle
Parameter.Description: How much should randomly be added or subtracted from the particle's direction per step.

Function.Name: part_type_direction

Function.Description: With this function you can check to see if the given particle type indexed exists in the game or not. Note that if the variable being checked is an uninitialised variable (that a particle type would otherwise have its index assigned to) this will throw an error.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to check for.

Function.Name: part_type_exists

Function.Description: This function will set the gravity that is to affect each particle of the given type that is created. The gravity strength value is added to the particle speed every step and is usually a small value like 0.5, while the direction is the direction of the gravity "pull" and follows the standard GameMaker directions of 0 being right, 90 being up, 180 being left and 270 being down.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to change.

Parameter.Name: grav_amount
Parameter.Description: Strength of the gravity.

Parameter.Name: grav_direction
Parameter.Description: The direction of the gravity.

Function.Name: part_type_gravity

Function.Description: This is the function that governs how long each individual particle of the indicated type remains on the screen. As with other particle functions, you provide a minimum and a maximum value (in steps)and each particle lifespan will be a random number of steps from within the specified range. To have all particles with the same lifetime, set the two values to be the same.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to change.

Parameter.Name: life_min
Parameter.Description: The minimum lifespan of the particles.

Parameter.Name: life_max
Parameter.Description: The maximum lifespan of the particles.

Function.Name: part_type_life

Function.Description: This function is used to determine the orientation of the particle sprite when it is created and can also be used to make the particle orientation increase or decrease over its lifetime. The minimum and maximum orientation values default at 0 but these values can be changed to randomise the orientation following the standard GameMaker directions of 0 degrees being right, 90 degrees being up, 180 degrees being left and 270 degrees being down. If you set them to the same value the particles will all be created with the same orientation.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to change.

Parameter.Name: ang_min
Parameter.Description: The minimum starting angle of the particles.

Parameter.Name: ang_max
Parameter.Description: The maximum starting angle of the particles.

Parameter.Name: ang_incr
Parameter.Description: The increase (or decrease if set negative) of the angle in degrees per step.

Parameter.Name: ang_wiggle
Parameter.Description: The amount the angle wiggles clockwise/counterclockwise per step.

Parameter.Name: ang_relative
Parameter.Description: Whether to set its angle relative to the direction of the particle's motion (true) or not (false).

Function.Name: part_type_orientation

Function.Description: This function will set the horizontal and vertical scale of the particle before any other size changes are made. This function works on the ratio of the sprite size, so a value of 1 (the default value) is a 1:1 ratio, meaning that 0.5 would be half and 2 double.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to change.

Parameter.Name: xscale
Parameter.Description: The horizontal scaling of the base particle.

Parameter.Name: yscale
Parameter.Description: The vertical scaling of the base particle.

Function.Name: part_type_scale

Function.Description: With this function you can set the sprite shape to use for the particle type, with the following constants being acceptable:

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to set.

Parameter.Name: shape
Parameter.Description: The shape to choose.

Function.Name: part_type_shape

Function.Description: This function is used to determine the size of the particle when it is created and can also be used to make the particle increase or decrease in size over its lifetime. The minimum and maximum size values default at 1 (meaning that the size is the same ratio as the base particle after the part_type_scale() scale has been set) and if they are set to the same value, the initial size for all particles will be the same, but if set to different values, each particle will start with a random size from within the range, for example if you have a minimum of 0.5 and a maximum of 2, all particles will be created with a size between half and double the base scale.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to change.

Parameter.Name: size_min
Parameter.Description: The minimum size the particle can start at.

Parameter.Name: size_max
Parameter.Description: The maximum size the particle can start at.

Parameter.Name: size_incr
Parameter.Description: How much the particle should increase or decrease per step.

Parameter.Name: size_wiggle
Parameter.Description: How much should randomly be added or subtracted from the particles size per step.

Function.Name: part_type_size

Function.Description: This function is used to configure particle size similarly to part_type_size(), except only for the x axis. You can use function part_type_size_y() to configure the size on the y axis separately as well.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to change.

Parameter.Name: size_min
Parameter.Description: The minimum size the particle can start at on the x axis.

Parameter.Name: size_max
Parameter.Description: The maximum size the particle can start at on the x axis.

Parameter.Name: size_incr
Parameter.Description: How much the particle should increase or decrease on the x axis per step.

Parameter.Name: size_wiggle
Parameter.Description: How much should randomly be added or subtracted from the particles size on the x axis per step.

Function.Name: part_type_size_x

Function.Description: This function is used to configure particle size similarly to part_type_size(), except only for the y axis. You can use function part_type_size_x() to configure the size on the x axis separately as well.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to change.

Parameter.Name: size_min
Parameter.Description: The minimum size the particle can start at on the y axis.

Parameter.Name: size_max
Parameter.Description: The maximum size the particle can start at on the y axis.

Parameter.Name: size_incr
Parameter.Description: How much the particle should increase or decrease on the y axis per step.

Parameter.Name: size_wiggle
Parameter.Description: How much should randomly be added or subtracted from the particles size on the y axis per step.

Function.Name: part_type_size_y

Function.Description: This function is used to set the movement speed of the particle when it is created and can also be used to make the particle increase or decrease its speed over its lifetime. The minimum and maximum speed values default at 1, which means that the particle will move 1 pixel each step, and if they are set to the same value, the initial speed for all particles will be the same, but if set to different values, each particle will start with a random speed from within the given range. For example if you have a minimum of 3 and a maximum of 6, all particles will be created with a speed between three and six pixels per step.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to change.

Parameter.Name: speed_min
Parameter.Description: The minimum speed the particle can start at.

Parameter.Name: speed_max
Parameter.Description: The maximum speed the particle can start at.

Parameter.Name: speed_incr
Parameter.Description: How much the particle speed should increase or decrease per step.

Parameter.Name: speed_wiggle
Parameter.Description: How much should randomly be added or subtracted from the particle's speed per step.

Function.Name: part_type_speed

Function.Description: This function can be used to set a particle type to use a custom sprite from the game assets. You can select the sprite and then tell GameMaker to use the sprite and animate it or not, and if you choose animated, then you can also choose to have the sub-images changed at an interval such that the animation will begin and end at the beginning and end of the lifetime of each particle created (so that if you have a lifetime set to a 15 step minimum and a 30 step maximum, no matter what value the lifetime has the animation will be made to fit, with it running faster for the shorter lifetimes and slower for the longer). You can also select to choose a random sub-image so that if the sprite is not animated, a different image will be chosen at random to create the sprite, or if the particle is animated it will start the animation at a random point.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to change.

Parameter.Name: sprite
Parameter.Description: The index of the sprite to set the particle type to.

Parameter.Name: animate
Parameter.Description: Whether to follow the sprite's animation normally (true) or not (false).

Parameter.Name: stretch
Parameter.Description: Whether to stretch the sprite's animation to match the particle lifespan (true) or not (false).

Parameter.Name: random
Parameter.Description: Whether to choose a random sub-image (true) or not (false).

Function.Name: part_type_sprite

Function.Description: This function can be used to set a particle type to use a custom sub-image (frame) of a sprite. If the particle's sprite is animated, then this sub-image will be used as the starting frame of the animation.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to change.

Parameter.Name: subimg
Parameter.Description: The sub-image (frame) of the sprite to use.

Function.Name: part_type_subimage

Function.Description: This function can be used to make your particle type stream another type each step until the end of its lifetime. You can set a negative value for the step number and a particle will be emitted at a random interval based on that, so that, for example, a value of -3 will have a 1:3 chance of emitting a particle each step.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to change.

Parameter.Name: step_number
Parameter.Description: The quantity of the new particle to create per step.

Parameter.Name: step_type
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to create.

Function.Name: part_type_step

Function.Description: This function must be called before you can define any primitives. There are 6 types of primitives you can define with the following constants:

Parameter.Name: kind
Parameter.Description: The kind of primitive you are going to draw.

Function.Name: draw_primitive_begin

Function.Description: This function must be called before you define the vertices of a textured primitive. You must give the kind of primitive to use (see draw_primitive_begin() for more information) and the id of a texture to use, which can be a sprite or background image asset. This asset id can be gotten from the functions sprite_get_texture(), for example (use -1 for no texture).

Parameter.Name: kind
Parameter.Description: The kind of primitive you are going to draw.

Parameter.Name: tex
Parameter.Description: The texture to use with the primitive.

Function.Name: draw_primitive_begin_texture

Function.Description: This function must be called when you have finished defining the points of your primitive. If you do not call this function, nothing will be drawn as this effectively tells GameMaker that you have finished and that it can now draw the defined primitive.
Function.Name: draw_primitive_end

Function.Description: This function defines the position of a vertex for a primitive. The final look of the primitive will depend on the primitive type chosen to draw and the order with which you add the vertexes to it. See draw_primitive_begin() for more information. To end and draw the primitive you must call draw_primitive_end().

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of the vertex.

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of the vertex.

Function.Name: draw_vertex

Function.Description: This function defines the position of a vertex for a primitive, with its own colour and alpha setting. The final look of the primitive will depend on the primitive type chosen to draw and the order with which you add the vertexes to it (see draw_primitive_begin() for more information) and the vertexes with different colours and alphas will blend smoothly from one to the other. To end and draw the primitive you must call draw_primitive_end().

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of the vertex.

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of the vertex.

Parameter.Name: col
Parameter.Description: The colour to draw this vertex with.

Parameter.Name: alpha
Parameter.Description: The alpha to draw this vertex with (0-1).

Function.Name: draw_vertex_colour

Function.Description: This function defines the position of a textured vertex for a primitive. The final look of the primitive will depend on the primitive type chosen to draw (See draw_primitive_begin() for more information), the order with which you add the vertexes to it and the position of the start point you set for the texture. To end and draw the primitive you must call draw_primitive_end().
Function.Name: draw_vertex_texture

Function.Description: This function defines the position of a textured vertex for a primitive. The final look of the primitive will depend on the primitive type chosen to draw (See draw_primitive_begin() for more information), the order with which you add the vertices to it, the position of the start and end points that you give for the texture sample and the colour and alpha values that you have set. To maintain the texture appearance while changing only the alpha, a value of -1 (or c_white) may be used for the colour argument. To end and draw the primitive you must call draw_primitive_end().

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of the vertex.

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of the vertex.

Parameter.Name: xtex
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate within the texture.

Parameter.Name: ytex
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate within the texture.

Parameter.Name: col
Parameter.Description: The colour to blend with the texture at this vertex (-1 or c_white for no blending).

Parameter.Name: alpha
Parameter.Description: The alpha to draw this vertex with (0-1).

Function.Name: draw_vertex_texture_colour

Function.Description: This function will set the ARGB values for the vertex currently being defined for the custom primitive. You supply the buffer to write the data into as well as the red, green, blue and alpha values that you wish to use as a single 32-bit unsigned integer - alpha sample in the highest 8 bits, followed by the red sample, green sample and finally the blue sample in the lowest 8 bits. You can use hex notation ($AARRGGBB) a real number or use any of the make_colour_*() functions to define the colour value.

Parameter.Name: buffer
Parameter.Description: The buffer to write the information to.

Parameter.Name: argb
Parameter.Description: The ARGB value to set.

Function.Name: vertex_argb

Function.Description: With this function you begin the definition of a custom primitive. You assign a buffer to write the primitive to, and the vertex format to use (previously defined using the vertex format functions). You would then define the necessary points for each vertex of the primitive before calling vertex_end() to finalise the primitive creation.

Parameter.Name: buffer
Parameter.Description: The buffer to be written to.

Parameter.Name: format
Parameter.Description: The vertex format to use.

Function.Name: vertex_begin

Function.Description: If your defined vertex format takes a colour value you can use this function to add that data to the vertex being defined for the current primitive. The function needs a buffer to store the data in and will take either a colour constant, or a hex value (using the standard GameMaker format of BGR, eg: $FF0000 for blue) as well as an alpha value from 0 (transparent) to 1 (fully opaque).

Parameter.Name: buffer
Parameter.Description: The buffer to write the information to.

Parameter.Name: colour
Parameter.Description: The colour for this vertex (can be a constant or a hex value).

Parameter.Name: alpha
Parameter.Description: The alpha value for the vertex (from 0 to 1).

Function.Name: vertex_colour

Function.Description: With this function you can create a new vertex buffer. This is a special grow buffer created by GameMaker which is pre-formatted for use when building primitives (for use with shaders, for example). The function will return a "Pointer" (index) for the buffer which should then be used in all further calls to it.
Function.Name: vertex_create_buffer

Function.Description: As with the function vertex_create_buffer(), this function will create a new vertex buffer. This is a special grow buffer created by GameMaker which is pre-formatted for use when building primitives for use with shaders. You can specify an initial starting size for the buffer (in bytes) and it will return a "handle" (index) for the buffer which should then be used in all further calls to the buffer.

Parameter.Name: size
Parameter.Description: The initial size of the buffer (in bytes).

Function.Name: vertex_create_buffer_ext

Function.Description: As with the function vertex_create_buffer(), this function will create a new vertex buffer, only now the vertex data it stores is copied from the regular buffer that is specified as the source. The buffer created is a special grow buffer which is pre-formatted with the vertex format for building primitives for use with (for example) shaders. This function requires that you supply the pointer to a previously created regular buffer, and a vertex format that should be applied to the copied data.

Parameter.Name: buffer
Parameter.Description: The buffer to create the vertex buffer from.

Parameter.Name: format
Parameter.Description: The primitive vertex format to use.

Function.Name: vertex_create_buffer_from_buffer

Function.Description: As with the function vertex_create_buffer(), this function will create a new vertex buffer, only now the vertex data it stores is copied from the regular buffer that is specified as the source. The buffer is pre-formatted with the vertex format for building primitives for use with (for example) shaders, and you can also supply an offset within the source buffer to copy from and the number of vertices that the final buffer should have. Note that if the number of vertices does not match those being copied you may get corrupted vertex data.

Parameter.Name: buffer
Parameter.Description: The buffer to create the vertex buffer from.

Parameter.Name: format
Parameter.Description: The primitive vertex format to use.

Parameter.Name: src_offset
Parameter.Description: The offset within the the source buffer to copy from.

Parameter.Name: vert_num
Parameter.Description: The number of vertices the buffer should have.

Function.Name: vertex_create_buffer_from_buffer_ext

Function.Description: This function updates contents of a vertex buffer using data from a regular buffer. The vertex buffer must not be frozen!

Parameter.Name: dest_vbuff
Parameter.Description: The vertex buffer to copy to.

Parameter.Name: dest_offset
Parameter.Description: The offset (in bytes) within the vertex buffer to copy to.

Parameter.Name: src_buffer
Parameter.Description: The buffer to copy data from.

Parameter.Name: src_offset
Parameter.Description: The offset (in bytes) within the buffer to copy from.

Parameter.Name: src_size
Parameter.Description: The size (in bytes) of data to be copied.

Function.Name: vertex_update_buffer_from_buffer

Function.Description: This function updates contents of a vertex buffer using contents of another vertex buffer. The vertex buffers must not be frozen!

Parameter.Name: dest_vbuff
Parameter.Description: The destination vertex buffer to copy to.

Parameter.Name: dest_vert
Parameter.Description: The index of the first vertex within the destination vertex buffer to copy to.

Parameter.Name: src_vbuff
Parameter.Description: The source vertex buffer to copy vertices from.

Parameter.Name: src_vert
Parameter.Description: The index of the first vertex to copy from the source vertex buffer.

Parameter.Name: src_vert_num
Parameter.Description: The number of vertices to copy.

Function.Name: vertex_update_buffer_from_vertex

Function.Description: This function can be used to remove a previously created vertex buffer (see vertex_create_buffer()) from system memory. This will also remove all vertex data for any custom primitives that it contained.

Parameter.Name: buffer
Parameter.Description: The buffer to be removed.

Function.Name: vertex_delete_buffer

Function.Description: With this function you end the building of the custom primitive. Once you call this command the primitive can be used in the vertex_submit() function for use in a shader or you can freeze the buffer (making the vertex buffer used read-only and much faster) using vertex_freeze().

Parameter.Name: buffer
Parameter.Description: The buffer to end writing to.

Function.Name: vertex_end

Function.Description: This function will add a floating point value to the vertex data. The vertex must have been formatted correctly to accept this using the vertex_format_add_custom() function.

Parameter.Name: buffer
Parameter.Description: The buffer to write the information to.

Parameter.Name: float
Parameter.Description: The input value.

Function.Name: vertex_float1

Function.Description: This function will add two floating point values to the vertex data. The vertex must have been formatted correctly to accept this using the vertex_format_add_custom() function.

Parameter.Name: buffer
Parameter.Description: The buffer to write the information to.

Parameter.Name: float
Parameter.Description: The first input value.

Parameter.Name: float
Parameter.Description: The second input value.

Function.Name: vertex_float2

Function.Description: This function will add three floating point values to the vertex data. The vertex must have been formatted correctly to accept this using the vertex_format_add_custom() function.

Parameter.Name: buffer
Parameter.Description: The buffer to write the information to.

Parameter.Name: float
Parameter.Description: The first input value.

Parameter.Name: float
Parameter.Description: The second input value.

Parameter.Name: float
Parameter.Description: The third input value.

Function.Name: vertex_float3

Function.Description: This function will add four floating point values to the vertex data. The vertex must have been formatted correctly to accept this using the vertex_format_add_custom() function.

Parameter.Name: buffer
Parameter.Description: The buffer to write the information to.

Parameter.Name: float
Parameter.Description: The first input value.

Parameter.Name: float
Parameter.Description: The second input value.

Parameter.Name: float
Parameter.Description: The third input value.

Parameter.Name: float
Parameter.Description: The fourth input value.

Function.Name: vertex_float4

Function.Description: Tell GameMaker to accept colour data as part of the new vertex format being created.
Function.Name: vertex_format_add_colour

Function.Description: This function permits you to use a custom data type for specific vertex format attributes as part of the new vertex format being created. The available values to use are defined by the data type constant that you choose, listed below:

Parameter.Name: type
Parameter.Description: The data type that this custom vertex data will hold (see the type constants listed below).

Parameter.Name: usage
Parameter.Description: The use that the data will get(see the usage constants listed below).

Function.Name: vertex_format_add_custom

Function.Description: Tell GameMaker to accept surface normal data (nx, ny and nz) as part of the new vertex format being created.
Function.Name: vertex_format_add_normal

Function.Description: Tell GameMaker to accept 2D positional data (x and y) as part of the new vertex format being created.
Function.Name: vertex_format_add_position

Function.Description: Tell GameMaker to accept 3D positional data (x, y and z) as part of the new vertex format being created.
Function.Name: vertex_format_add_position_3d

Function.Description: Tell GameMaker to accept texture position data (u and v) as part of the new vertex format being created.
Function.Name: vertex_format_add_texcoord

Function.Description: Before you can define your new vertex format you must tell GameMaker that you're doing so using this function. You must call this first, then define the format values using the appropriate functions, and finally call vertex_format_end() to finish the definition and return the new format "handle".
Function.Name: vertex_format_begin

Function.Description: This function must be called whenever you are finished using any created vector formats. You provide the format ID value (as returned by the function vector_format_end()), and this function will free the memory associated with it. Note that if you try to use this format again after calling this function, you will get an error.
Function.Name: vertex_format_delete

Function.Description: This function must be called after defining any new vertex format. It returns the new format "handle" (index) which must be used in all further vertex functions that refer to this new format.
Function.Name: vertex_format_end

Function.Description: This function is used to retrieve information for the given vertex format. You supply a vertex format index and the function returns a struct with the following variables:

Parameter.Name: format_id
Parameter.Description: The vertex format for which information should be retrieved.

Function.Name: vertex_format_get_info

Function.Description: This function can be used to "freeze" a vertex buffer. this buffer becomes read-only, meaning that should you need to change it, you would have to delete the whole buffer and re-create it. A frozen buffer can be submitted to the shader faster than a normal, dynamic buffer and is recommended for those effects that require an unchanging custom primitive for the duration of a level or the game.

Parameter.Name: buffer
Parameter.Description: The buffer to freeze.

Function.Name: vertex_freeze

Function.Description: With this function you can get the size of the given vertex buffer in bytes.

Parameter.Name: buffer
Parameter.Description: The buffer to get the size of.

Function.Name: vertex_get_buffer_size

Function.Description: With this function you can find out the number of individual vertices defined in any given vertex buffer.

Parameter.Name: buffer
Parameter.Description: The vertex buffer to check.

Function.Name: vertex_get_number

Function.Description: This function will add surface normal data to the vertex currently being defined for the custom primitive. You supply the buffer to write the data into as well as the x, y and z component parts of the normal.

Parameter.Name: buffer
Parameter.Description: The buffer to write the information to.

Parameter.Name: nx
Parameter.Description: The x component of the surface normal.

Parameter.Name: ny
Parameter.Description: The y component of the surface normal.

Parameter.Name: nz
Parameter.Description: The z component of the surface normal.

Function.Name: vertex_normal

Function.Description: This function will add 2D position data to the vertex currently being defined for the custom primitive. You supply the buffer to write the data into as well as the x and y position for drawing.

Parameter.Name: buffer
Parameter.Description: The buffer to write the information to.

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x position.

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y position.

Function.Name: vertex_position

Function.Description: This function will add 3D position data to the vertex currently being defined for the custom primitive. You supply the buffer to write the data into as well as the x, y and z position for drawing.

Parameter.Name: buffer
Parameter.Description: The buffer to write the information to.

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x position.

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y position.

Parameter.Name: z
Parameter.Description: The z position.

Function.Name: vertex_position_3d

Function.Description: You can use this function to submit the contents of a vertex buffer to the graphics pipeline for use with a shader. You supply the buffer index to use, the base primitive type to use (see the constants below) and the texture that is to be used. The base primitive type is only used for assigning the order in which the vertexes that you stored in the buffer are drawn and connected, but the actual data used for each of the vertexes will be that which you defined when creating the vertex buffer.

Parameter.Name: buffer
Parameter.Description: The buffer to use.

Parameter.Name: primitive
Parameter.Description: The primitive base type.

Parameter.Name: texture
Parameter.Description: The texture to use (or -1 for no texture).

Function.Name: vertex_submit

Function.Description: This function will set the texture coordinates to use for the vertex currently being defined for the custom primitive. You supply the buffer to write the data into as well as the UV position within the texture to use.

Parameter.Name: buffer
Parameter.Description: The buffer to write the information to.

Parameter.Name: u
Parameter.Description: The first texture coordinate to use (0 - 1).

Parameter.Name: v
Parameter.Description: The second texture coordinate to use (0 - 1).

Function.Name: vertex_texcoord

Function.Description: This function will add four unsigned byte values (0 - 255) to the vertex data. The vertex must have been formatted correctly to accept this using the vertex_format_add_custom() function.

Parameter.Name: buffer
Parameter.Description: The buffer to write the information to.

Parameter.Name: byte
Parameter.Description: The first input value.

Parameter.Name: byte
Parameter.Description: The second input value.

Parameter.Name: byte
Parameter.Description: The third input value.

Parameter.Name: byte
Parameter.Description: The fourth input value.

Function.Name: vertex_ubyte4

Function.Description: With this function you can enable or disable anti-aliasing (AA) for SWF format vector sprites. AA simply smooths the edges of vector images to give them a nicer look. The amount of AA used will depend on the value set using the function draw_set_swf_aa_level(). By default this is disabled.

Parameter.Name: enable
Parameter.Description: Enable (true) or disable (false) AA for all SWF sprites.

Function.Name: draw_enable_swf_aa

Function.Description: This function can be used to get the anti-aliasing (AA) level for SWF format vector sprites. The return value will between 0 and 1 and shows how "smooth" the edges of these sprites will be drawn. You can set the AA level using the function draw_set_swf_aa_level().
Function.Name: draw_get_swf_aa_level

Function.Description: This function draws the sprite assigned to the instance exactly as it would be drawn if the draw event held no code or actions, and will reflect and changes that have been made to the sprite variables in other events.
Function.Name: draw_self

Function.Description: This function can be used to set the anti-aliasing (AA) level for SWF format vector sprites. This can be a real value from 0 to 1 and will "smooth" the edges of these sprites. Note that to see this effect, you must first have enabled AA using the function draw_enable_swf_aa().

Parameter.Name: aa
Parameter.Description: The anti-aliasing value to use from 0 to 1.

Function.Name: draw_set_swf_aa_level

Function.Description: This function draws the given sprite and sub-image at a position within the game room. For the sprite you can use the instance variable sprite_index to get the current sprite that is assigned to the instance running the code, or you can use any other sprite asset. The same goes for the sub-image, as this can also be set to the instance variable image_index which will set the sub-image to that selected for the current instance sprite (note, that you can draw a different sprite and still use the sub-image value for the current instance), or you can use any other value for this to draw a specific sub-image of the chosen sprite. If the value is larger than the number of sub-images, then GameMaker will automatically loop the number to select the corresponding image (for example, if the sprite being drawn has 5 sub-images numbered 0 to 4 and we set the index value to 7, then the function will draw sub-image 3, numbered 0). Finally, the x and y position is the position within the room that the sprite will be drawn, and it is centered on the sprite x offset and y offset.

Parameter.Name: sprite
Parameter.Description: The index of the sprite to draw.

Parameter.Name: subimg
Parameter.Description: The sub-image (frame) of the sprite to draw (image_index or -1 correlate to the current frame of animation in the object).

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

Function.Name: draw_sprite

Function.Description: This function will draw the given sprite as in the function draw_sprite() but with additional options to change the scale, blending, rotation and alpha of the sprite being drawn. Changing these values does not modify the resource in any way (only how it is drawn), and you can use any of the available sprite variables instead of direct values for all the arguments in the function. The image below illustrates how different values affect the drawing of the sprite:

Parameter.Name: sprite
Parameter.Description: The index of the sprite to draw.

Parameter.Name: subimg
Parameter.Description: The subimg (frame) of the sprite to draw (image_index or -1 correlate to the current frame of animation in the object).

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

Parameter.Name: xscale
Parameter.Description: The horizontal scaling of the sprite, as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...

Parameter.Name: yscale
Parameter.Description: The vertical scaling of the sprite as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...

Parameter.Name: rot
Parameter.Description: The rotation of the sprite. 0=right way up, 90=rotated 90 degrees counter-clockwise etc...

Parameter.Name: colour
Parameter.Description: The colour with which to blend the sprite. c_white is to display it normally.

Parameter.Name: alpha
Parameter.Description: The alpha of the sprite (from 0 to 1 where 0 is transparent and 1 opaque).

Function.Name: draw_sprite_ext

Function.Description: This function combines the function draw_sprite_ext() with the function draw_sprite_part(), adding in some additional blending options so that each corner of the final sprite part can be blended with an individual colour.

Parameter.Name: sprite
Parameter.Description: The index of the sprite to draw.

Parameter.Name: subimg
Parameter.Description: The subimg (frame) of the sprite to draw (image_index or -1 correlate to the current frame of animation in the object).

Parameter.Name: left
Parameter.Description: The x position on the sprite of the top left corner of the area to draw.

Parameter.Name: top
Parameter.Description: The y position on the sprite of the top left corner of the area to draw.

Parameter.Name: width
Parameter.Description: The width of the area to draw.

Parameter.Name: height
Parameter.Description: The height of the area to draw.

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

Parameter.Name: xscale
Parameter.Description: The horizontal scaling of the sprite, as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...

Parameter.Name: yscale
Parameter.Description: The vertical scaling of the sprite, as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...

Parameter.Name: rot
Parameter.Description: The rotation of the sprite. 0=normal, 90=turned 90 degrees counter-clockwise etc.

Parameter.Name: c1
Parameter.Description: The colour with which to blend the top left area of the sprite.

Parameter.Name: c2
Parameter.Description: The colour with which to blend the top right area of the sprite.

Parameter.Name: c3
Parameter.Description: The colour with which to blend the bottom right area of the sprite.

Parameter.Name: c4
Parameter.Description: The colour with which to blend the bottom left area of the sprite.

Parameter.Name: alpha
Parameter.Description: The alpha of the sprite (from 0 to 1 where 0 is transparent and 1 opaque).

Function.Name: draw_sprite_general

Function.Description: With this function you can draw part of any sprite at a given position within the room. As with draw_sprite() you can specify a sprite and a sub-image for drawing, then you must give the relative coordinates within the sprite of the area to select for drawing. This means that a left position of 0 and a top position of 0 would be the top left corner of the sprite and all further coordinates should be taken from that position. The image below shows an example of how this works:

Parameter.Name: sprite
Parameter.Description: The index of the sprite to draw.

Parameter.Name: subimg
Parameter.Description: The subimg (frame) of the sprite to draw (image_index or -1 correlate to the current frame of animation in the object).

Parameter.Name: left
Parameter.Description: The x position on the sprite of the top left corner of the area to draw.

Parameter.Name: top
Parameter.Description: The y position on the sprite of the top left corner of the area to draw.

Parameter.Name: width
Parameter.Description: The width of the area to draw.

Parameter.Name: height
Parameter.Description: The height of the area to draw.

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

Function.Name: draw_sprite_part

Function.Description: This function will draw a part of the chosen sprite at the given position following the same rules as per draw_sprite_part(), only now you can scale the part, blend a colour with it, or change its alpha when drawing it to the screen (the same as when drawing a sprite with draw_sprite_ext()). You should note that if the texture page permits automatic cropping then this function may not work as expected, since the extra "empty" space around the sprite will have been removed for creating the texture page. To resolve this issue, you will need to set the texture page settings (in the Texture Group Editor) to disable the Automatic Crop.

Parameter.Name: sprite
Parameter.Description: The index of the sprite to draw.

Parameter.Name: subimg
Parameter.Description: The subimg (frame) of the sprite to draw (image_index or -1 correlate to the current frame of animation in the object).

Parameter.Name: left
Parameter.Description: The x position on the sprite of the top left corner of the area to draw.

Parameter.Name: top
Parameter.Description: The y position on the sprite of the top left corner of the area to draw.

Parameter.Name: width
Parameter.Description: The width of the area to draw.

Parameter.Name: height
Parameter.Description: The height of the area to draw.

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

Parameter.Name: xscale
Parameter.Description: The horizontal scaling of the sprite, as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...

Parameter.Name: yscale
Parameter.Description: The vertical scaling of the sprite, as a multiplier: 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc...

Parameter.Name: colour
Parameter.Description: The colour with which to blend the sprite. c_white is to display it normally.

Parameter.Name: alpha
Parameter.Description: The alpha of the sprite (from 0 to 1 where 0 is transparent and 1 opaque).

Function.Name: draw_sprite_part_ext

Function.Description: With this function you can draw a sprite distorted over the area defined by the four corner coordinates. The first two arguments are the sprite to draw and the sub-image of the sprite (the same as in the function draw_sprite()) but the next ones are those that define the position of each of the four corners of the bounding box of the given sprite. These should be given in clockwise order, so the first coordinate is the top left, then the top right, then bottom right and finally the bottom left. You can also set a value for the alpha of the sprite to draw it with transparency. The image below illustrates how this function works:

Parameter.Name: sprite
Parameter.Description: The index of the sprite to draw.

Parameter.Name: subimg
Parameter.Description: The subimg (frame) of the sprite to draw (image_index or -1 correlate to the current frame of animation in the object).

Parameter.Name: x1
Parameter.Description: The first x coordinate.

Function.Name: draw_sprite_pos

Function.Description: This function simply takes a sprite resource and stretches it over the given width and height so that it occupies that area. As with draw_sprite() you can specify a sprite and a sub-image for drawing, then the x / y position in the room for the sprite to be drawn at and finally a width and a height (which must be pixel values). The image below shows the result of this function with different sets of arguments:

Parameter.Name: sprite
Parameter.Description: The index of the sprite to draw.

Parameter.Name: subimg
Parameter.Description: The subimg (frame) of the sprite to draw (image_index or -1 correlate to the current frame of animation in the object).

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

Parameter.Name: w
Parameter.Description: The width of the area the stretched sprite will occupy.

Parameter.Name: h
Parameter.Description: The height of the area the stretched sprite will occupy.

Function.Name: draw_sprite_stretched

Function.Description: This function does exactly the same as the draw_sprite_stretched() function with the added ability to set the colour blending and alpha value for the sprite when it is drawn (similar to the function draw_sprite_ext()).

Parameter.Name: sprite
Parameter.Description: The index of the sprite to draw.

Parameter.Name: subimg
Parameter.Description: The subimg (frame) of the sprite to draw (image_index or -1 correlate to the current frame of animation in the object).

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

Parameter.Name: w
Parameter.Description: The width of the area the stretched sprite will occupy.

Parameter.Name: h
Parameter.Description: The height of the area the stretched sprite will occupy.

Parameter.Name: colour
Parameter.Description: The colour with which to blend the sprite. c_white is to display it normally.

Parameter.Name: alpha
Parameter.Description: The alpha of the sprite (from 0 to 1 where 0 is transparent and 1 opaque).

Function.Name: draw_sprite_stretched_ext

Function.Description: This function will take a sprite and then repeatedly tile it across the whole view (or room if no view is defined), starting from the coordinates that you give in the function. Tiling is based on the width and height of the sprite as defined by the sprite variables of the instance running the code. This function is for 2D (orthographic) projections only, and will not work correctly when a 3D camera projection is used.

Parameter.Name: sprite
Parameter.Description: The index of the sprite to draw.

Parameter.Name: subimg
Parameter.Description: The subimg (frame) of the sprite to draw (image_index or -1 correlate to the current frame of animation in the object).

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

Function.Name: draw_sprite_tiled

Function.Description: This function will take a sprite and then repeatedly tile it across the whole view (or room if no view is defined), starting from the coordinates that you give in the function and with each tile scaled, colour blended and with the alpha that you define (these properties are the same as those used in draw_sprite_ext()). This function is for 2D (orthographic) projections only, and will not work correctly when a 3D camera projection is used.

Parameter.Name: sprite
Parameter.Description: The index of the sprite to draw.

Parameter.Name: subimg
Parameter.Description: The subimg (frame) of the sprite to draw (image_index or -1 correlate to the current frame of animation in the object).

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of where to draw the sprite.

Parameter.Name: xscale
Parameter.Description: The horizontal scaling of the sprite. A multiplier ' 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc.

Parameter.Name: yscale
Parameter.Description: The vertical scaling of the sprite. A multiplier ' 1 = normal scaling, 0.5 is half etc.

Parameter.Name: colour
Parameter.Description: The colour with which to blend the sprite. c_white is to display it normally.

Parameter.Name: alpha
Parameter.Description: The alpha of the sprite (from 0 to 1 where 0 is transparent and 1 opaque).

Function.Description: With this function you can draw any given tile from a tile set - compete with rotations, flips and mirrors - setting the frame (if animated) and the position within the room. The tile set ID value is the tile set index as set in the IDE and the tile data is the data "blob" that contains all the information about the tile index and the transformations that have been applied. You can use the function tilemap_get() to get the tile data which can then be manipulated using the Tile Functions, or you can construct it yourself using the following tile constants along with the index value of the tile to create:

Parameter.Name: tile set
Parameter.Description: The ID of the tile set to use

Parameter.Name: tiledata
Parameter.Description: The tile data to use

Parameter.Name: frame
Parameter.Description: The frame number for the animated tile to use (default 0 for non-animated tiles)

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x position within the room to draw at

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y position within the room to draw at

Function.Name: draw_tile

Function.Description: This function can be used to draw a given tilemap anywhere in the room. You give the tilemap element ID (which you get when you create a tilemap element using layer_tilemap_create() or when you use the function layer_tilemap_get_id()), then give the x/y position for drawing (in the room). Note that this will simply draw the tilemap at the specified point, using the layer depth of the instance that is calling the function. It does not move the tilemap - nor change it in any way - and does it matter if the tilemap is flagged as visible or not.

Parameter.Name: tilemap_element_id
Parameter.Description: The unique ID value of the tilemap element to get the cell y position of

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x position within the room to draw at

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y position within the room to draw at

Function.Name: draw_tilemap

Function.Description: When you have "maintain aspect ratio" ticked in the Game Options for a target platform, GameMaker will automatically set the draw position for the application surface so that it is displayed correctly centered and scaled on the given display. However if you are manipulating this surface and wish to draw it yourself, then this function gives you an easy way to find exactly where within the display or window that the surface was being drawn so that you can then draw it there yourself, or align GUI images or post draw images to it.
Function.Name: application_get_position

Function.Description: You can use this function to enable or disable the automatic drawing of the application surface. By default this is enabled, but in many cases you will want to take over when and how the surface is drawn (when using shaders for example), in which case you would use this function to set it to false so that you can draw it yourself when and how you require. It's important to note that when you switch off automatic drawing and draw the application surface yourself, that you may see certain issues with the alpha component of sprites and the surface itself. This is because GameMaker will draw the application surface without alpha blending when the automatic drawing is on. If you switch off automatic drawing then you need to handle this yourself, using the following code (for example):

Parameter.Name: flag
Parameter.Description: The flag will be either true (enabled, the default value) or false (disabled).

Function.Name: application_surface_draw_enable

Function.Description: With this function you can enable or disable the application surface. By default the application surface is enabled and all drawing for the Draw events will be done to that and the surface drawn to the screen. However on some older devices and specific chipsets this may result in poorer performance. In those cases you can switch off drawing to the application surface and all Draw event drawing will then be done directly to the screen buffer.

Parameter.Name: enable
Parameter.Description: Set to enable (true) or disable (false) the application surface.

Function.Name: application_surface_enable

Function.Description: This function will return true if the application surface is being used for drawing, or false if the screen buffer is being used.
Function.Name: application_surface_is_enabled

Function.Description: With this function you can draw a surface at a given position within the room, with the top left corner of the image being drawn at the specified x/y position.

Function.Name: draw_surface

Function.Description: This function will draw the given surface as in the function draw_surface() but with additional options to change the scale, blending, rotation and alpha of the surface being drawn. Changing these values does not modify the resource in any way (only how it is drawn).

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x position of where to draw the surface.

Parameter.Description: The alpha transparency for drawing the surface.

Function.Description: This function simply takes the image from one surface and copies it onto another one at the specified local position within that surface (where the (0,0) position is the top left corner of the destination surface). If the destination surface already has information this will be overwritten by the copy, and the function does not change the source surface in any way.

Parameter.Name: destination
Parameter.Description: The ID of the surface to copy the other surface to.

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x position to copy to.

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y position to copy to.

Parameter.Name: source
Parameter.Description: The ID of surface to be copied.

Function.Name: surface_copy

Function.Description: This function simply takes the image from one surface and copies it onto another one at the specified local position within that surface (where the (0,0) position is the top left corner of the destination surface). You can specify a local x and y position to copy from as well as the width and height of the section. Please note that these are coordinates based on the surface size and not on the position at which the surface is being drawn in the room. If the destination surface already has information this will be overwritten by the copy, and the function does not change the source surface in any way.

Parameter.Name: destination
Parameter.Description: The ID of the surface to copy the other surface to.

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x position to copy to.

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y position to copy to.

Parameter.Name: source
Parameter.Description: The ID of the surface to be copied.

Parameter.Name: xs
Parameter.Description: The x position in the source surface to copy from.

Parameter.Name: ys
Parameter.Description: The y position in the source surface to copy from.

Parameter.Name: ws
Parameter.Description: The width of the area in the source surface to copy from.

Parameter.Name: hs
Parameter.Description: The height of the area in the source surface to copy from.

Function.Name: surface_copy_part

Function.Description: This function is used to create a surface and will return the index of the surface which should be stored in a variable for future function calls. When the surface is first created, it may contain "noise" as basically it is just an area of memory that is put aside for the purpose (and that memory may still contain information), so you may want to clear the surface before use with a function like draw_clear_alpha().

Parameter.Name: w
Parameter.Description: The width of the surface to be created.

Parameter.Name: h
Parameter.Description: The height of the surface to be created.

Parameter.Name: format
Parameter.Description: The format of the surface to be created.

Function.Name: surface_create

Function.Description: This function allows you to attach a surface to a canvas element that already exists in your web page, meaning that you can effectively split up portions of your game to be drawn at various different places within the page. To that end, you must have defined the canvas element correctly within the *.html page of your game using the correct sizes and names that correspond to the surfaces you wish to create. So, you would have your "main" canvas, and then your secondary surface canvas elements, which will be assigned using this function to the correct surfaces. The following image is an example of how a page with three canvas elements would be set up:

Parameter.Name: name
Parameter.Description: The name of the canvas element to link the surface to.

Parameter.Name: w
Parameter.Description: The width of the surface to be created.

Parameter.Name: h
Parameter.Description: The height of the surface to be created.

Function.Name: surface_create_ext

Function.Description: This function is used to test whether the specified surface format is supported on the current platform.

Parameter.Name: format
Parameter.Description: The surface format to be tested.

Function.Name: surface_format_is_supported

Function.Description: This function disables the automatic depth buffer generation for all surfaces that are created after it has been disabled. Normally all surfaces have depth buffers so if you draw 3D objects to them then it'll sort them properly by depth in order to maintain functional parity between rendering to surfaces and rendering to the back buffer, however allocating depth buffers essentially doubles the amount of memory required for surfaces, which could be an excessive and unnecessary overhead especially if your game is very memory intensive, and for 2D games they aren't generally required.

Parameter.Name: disable
Parameter.Description: If set to true the depth buffer will be disabled for created surfaces.

Function.Name: surface_depth_disable

Function.Description: This function is essential when working with surfaces due to their volatile nature. Surfaces are always held in texture memory which means that they can be destroyed from one moment to the next (for example, when a screensaver starts on windows, or when minimised on an Android device), so you should always check that a surface exists before doing anything with it (this includes drawing it to the screen). The example code below shows a typical use of this command in the draw event of an instance to check for a surface and re-create it if it has been removed (note that the surface will have been originally created in the create event of the object).

Parameter.Name: surface_id
Parameter.Description: The ID of the surface to check.

Function.Name: surface_exists

Function.Description: When you are working with surfaces, you should always use this function whenever you are finished using them. Surfaces take up space in memory and so need to be removed, normally at the end of a room, but it can be done at any time depending on the use you put them to. Failure to do so can cause memory leaks which will eventually slow down and crash your game.

Parameter.Name: surface_id
Parameter.Description: The ID of the surface to be freed.

Function.Name: surface_free

Function.Description: This function can be used to get the colour of a specific pixel from a surface, using the local coordinates of the surface where (0,0) is the top left corner. This function should not be used very often as it is extremely slow and may cause a pause in your game.

Parameter.Name: surface_id
Parameter.Description: The ID of the surface.

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x position on the surface from which to get the pixel.

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y position on the surface from which to get the pixel.

Function.Name: surface_getpixel

Function.Description: With this function you can get the full abgr 32bit value of any pixel of a (previously created) surface.

Parameter.Name: surface_id
Parameter.Description: The ID of the surface to use.

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of the pixel to check

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of the pixel to check

Function.Name: surface_getpixel_ext

Function.Description: This function checks to see if the automatic depth buffer generation for surfaces is enabled. Normally all surfaces have depth buffers so if you draw 3D objects to them then it'll sort them properly by depth, however allocating depth buffers essentially doubles the size of surfaces, which could be an excessive and unnecessary overhead especially if your game is very memory intensive or predominantly 2D. In these cases you can check this using this function and disable the depth buffer for surfaces if required using the function surface_depth_disable().
Function.Name: surface_get_depth_disable

Function.Description: This function simply returns the height, in pixels, of the indexed surface. It should be noted that if you call this to check the application_surface immediately after having changed its size using surface_resize() it will not return the new value as the change needs a step or two to be fully processed. After waiting a step it should return the new size correctly.

Parameter.Name: surface_id
Parameter.Description: The ID of the surface to get the height of.

Function.Name: surface_get_height

Function.Description: With this function you can get the ID of the current surface being targeted for drawing to. If you created that surface using surface_create(), then this will be the positive integer which is the unique ID for that surface
Function.Name: surface_get_target

Function.Description: This function will retrieve the surface ID assigned to one of the 4 render targets available to surfaces. You supply the index of the render target to check, and the function will return -1 if no surface is assigned, or an integer value >= 0, representing the ID of the surface assigned (as returned by the function surface_create()).

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The render target index to check (from 0 to 3).

Function.Name: surface_get_target_ext

Function.Description: This function returns a special pointer for the surface texture. This value can then be used in other draw functions, particularly in general 3D and some of the 2D primitive functions.

Parameter.Name: surface_id
Parameter.Description: The ID of the surface to get the width of.

Function.Name: surface_get_texture

Function.Description: This function simply returns the width, in pixels, of the indexed surface. It should be noted that if you call this to check the application_surface immediately after having changed its size using surface_resize() it will not return the new value as the change needs a step or two to be fully processed. After waiting a step it should return the new size correctly.

Parameter.Name: surface_id
Parameter.Description: The ID of the surface to get the width of.

Function.Name: surface_get_width

Function.Description: With this function you reset all further drawing from the target surface back to the screen. Please note that to start drawing to a surface you must first have called the function surface_set_target() and then this one after you have finished, for each surface target that you have set or else nothing will be drawn on the screen as all further drawing (even in other instances) will be done on the surface. You should also realise that nothing will be seen if the surface itself is not drawn on the screen in the draw event of an instance.
Function.Name: surface_reset_target

Function.Description: This function will resize a surface to the given dimensions (in pixels). The "surface_id" is that of a surface you have created previously, or the application_suface, and the function will resize that surface. Note that this will neither crop nor stretch the contents of the surface, but rather it destroys the current surface and recreates it with the same handle (surface_id) with the new dimensions, meaning that it will need to be cleared and drawn to again (unless it is the application_surface in which case GameMaker will do this automatically).

Parameter.Name: surface_id
Parameter.Description: The ID of the surface to change.

Parameter.Name: w
Parameter.Description: The width of the new surface.

Parameter.Name: h
Parameter.Description: The height of the new surface.

Function.Name: surface_resize

Function.Description: This function will save a surface to disc using the given filename. The surface must be saved as a *.png format file.

Parameter.Name: surface_id
Parameter.Description: The ID of the surface to set as the drawing target.

Parameter.Name: fname
Parameter.Description: The name of the saved image file.

Function.Name: surface_save

Function.Description: This function will save a part of a surface to disc using the given filename. The surface must be saved as a *.png format file, and the (x,y) position must be given as local coordinates to the surface, bearing in mind that the top left corner of the surface is always (0,0).

Parameter.Name: surface_id
Parameter.Description: The ID of the surface to set as the drawing target.

Parameter.Name: fname
Parameter.Description: The name of the saved image file.

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The starting x position within the surface.

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The starting y position within the surface.

Parameter.Name: width
Parameter.Description: The width of the part to save.

Parameter.Name: height
Parameter.Description: The height of the part to save.

Function.Name: surface_save_part

Function.Description: With this function you set all further drawing to the target surface rather than the screen and in this way you can tell GameMaker to only draw specific things to the specified surface. Please note that if you do not call surface_reset_target() after you have finished, nothing will be drawn on the screen as all further drawing (even in other instances) will be done on the surface. You should also realise that nothing will be seen if the surface itself is not drawn on the screen in the draw event of an instance. You can check the return value of this function too as a debug tool to check whether the surface target was set or not, with a return value of 0 being a failure to set the target and any other positive value being a success.

Parameter.Name: surface_id
Parameter.Description: The ID of the surface to set as the drawing target.

Function.Name: surface_set_target

Function.Description: This function is for use with the Shader Functions and sets the MRT (0 - 3) for native level shaders (DX9, DX11, OpenGL).

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The render target index to use (from 0 to 3).

Parameter.Name: surface_id
Parameter.Description: The ID of the surface to use.

The colour of the text and the alpha are governed by the current base alpha and colour values as set by draw_set_alpha() and draw_set_colour().

Note that any white space placed at the start of the string will be stripped out before being parsed for drawing because of this. Also note that a value of -1 for the line separation argument will default to a separation based on the height of the "M" character in the chosen font.

Function.Description: This function is a combination of the base draw_text() function with the draw_text_ext() and draw_text_transformed() functions, permitting you to scale and rotate text while maintaining a specific line spacing and maximum width per line. Note that the "width" argument is based on a scale of 1, so if the scale is different, this value should be changed proportionally. For example, if the base width for a line break is 300 and you set the scale to 2, then the text will appear wrong, over-running the given width. Instead you should have set the width to 150 to compensate the scaling.

Note that the "width" argument is based on a scale of 1, so if the scale is different, this value should be changed proportionally. For example, if the base width for a line break is 300 and you set the scale to 2, then the text will appear wrong, over-running the given width.
