Function.Description: This function will set the shape of the particle group that is being created. You must first have begun the group definition using the function physics_particle_group_begin(), and then you would use this function to tell GameMaker that you are going to add in the approximate points that will be used to define the polygon shape - approximate because the exact shape will depend on the size of the base particles, as defined by the physics_particle_set_radius() function, as the physics simulation tries to "fit" as many of the particles as possible into the defined shape.
Function.Name: physics_particle_group_polygon

Function.Description: With this function you can change the particle flags for a category of particles. The category value is that which you defined in the function physics_particle_create() or (if you created a group) physics_particle_group_begin(), while the flags are the return value of a combination of the following constants:

Parameter.Name: category
Parameter.Description: The particle category to set.

Parameter.Name: flags
Parameter.Description: The flags to set on the particle.

Function.Name: physics_particle_set_category_flags

Function.Description: With this function you can set the linear damping of particles in the simulation. Damping is used to reduce the physics simulation velocity of instances over time, much like air resistance in the real world. This function is global in scope, in that it will change the damping not just for new particles created after the change, but also for those already present in the simulation.

Parameter.Name: damping
Parameter.Description: The linear damping to be applied to the particle fixture.

Function.Name: physics_particle_set_damping

Function.Description: With this function you can set the density of the particles in a physics simulation. Setting the density of the particle will have a direct impact on how much inertia it has as well as how it reacts to collisions, so if you make a small particle with a high density it will have a very large mass, but if you define a large particle with a low density it will have a much smaller mass. This function is global in scope, in that it will change the density not just for new particles created after the change, but also for those already present in the simulation.

Parameter.Name: density
Parameter.Description: The density of the particle fixture.

Function.Name: physics_particle_set_density

Function.Description: With this function you can change the particle flags for an individual particle. The index value is the particle ID as returned by the function physics_particle_create(), while the flags are the return value of a combination of the following constants:

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle.

Parameter.Name: flags
Parameter.Description: The flags to set on the particle.

Function.Name: physics_particle_set_flags

Function.Description: With this function you can set the gravity scale factor for particles in the physics simulation. The function is designed to help prevent instability in the physics simulation, especially when using very small particles which may behave unpredictably (i.e. break conservation of momentum) in scenarios such as explosions. Slowing these particles down by reducing gravity scale can stabilize their behaviour. This function is global in scope, in that it will change the gravity scale not just for new particles created after the change, but also for those already present in the simulation.

Parameter.Name: scale
Parameter.Description: The scaling factor to be applied to gravity for all particles.

Function.Name: physics_particle_set_gravity_scale

Function.Description: With this function you can change the group flags for a group of particles. The group value is that which was returned when you created the group of particles using the function physics_particle_group_end(), while the flags are the return value of a combination of the following constants:

Parameter.Name: group
Parameter.Description: The particle group to set.

Parameter.Name: flags
Parameter.Description: The flags to set on the particle.

Function.Name: physics_particle_set_group_flags

Function.Description: This function will set the total permitted number of particles in a physics simulation. If you set this value to 0, then there is no cap the particles created, and setting it to any other value will stop any further particles being created when the total number of particles is equal to the value. Note that the minimum number of particles you can create in a simulation is 128, so setting this value any lower will have no effect (unless set to 0).

Parameter.Name: count
Parameter.Description: The maximum number of particles to permit.

Function.Name: physics_particle_set_max_count

Function.Description: With this function you can set the radius (in pixels) for the particles in a physics simulation. This function is global in scope, in that it will change the radius not just for new particles created after the change, but also for those already present in the simulation.

Parameter.Name: radius
Parameter.Description: The radius (in pixels) of the particle fixture.

Function.Name: physics_particle_set_radius

Function.Description: When creating a physics system in GameMaker, it is often important to have a visual representation of what is actually happening with an instance. This can be achieved by using physics_draw_debug(), which draws a schematic outline of the physical properties associated with the instance running the code. Here is an image of how it looks:
Function.Name: physics_draw_debug

Function.Description: Normally for a physics simulation to work, it must be continuous and cannot be stopped and started, or have instances suddenly moved from one place to another in the room. However, there are moments when you need to pause the simulation as (for example) the device os has paused, and so you would use this function. It pauses the simulation if the flag is set to true and no further physics calculations will be done until the flag is set to false again.

Parameter.Name: flag
Parameter.Description: This can be set to true to pause the simulation, or false to start it again.

Function.Name: physics_pause_enable

Function.Description: Even if you have defined the physics for your objects, without a world to place them in they will default to the traditional GameMaker collision system, so you need this function to create the physics system for the specified room either in an object event, or the creation code of the room itself (it can also be defined without using code in the room editor). This function will associate a physics "world" with the room and all instances created in the room will behave using the physics that has been defined for them and the world itself.

Parameter.Name: pixeltometrescale
Parameter.Description: defines the ratio of pixels on screen to metres in the real world. A ratio of 32:1 will be specified as 1/32 (or 0.03125).

Function.Name: physics_world_create

Function.Description: This function will draw a representation of the physics world system of the room to help with debugging when you are having trouble getting the physics scene to work right. Sometimes the problem can be in the rendering part of your game, for example a sprite may be drawn at the wrong position or rotation, giving the appearance of incorrect physics, or it may be that your calculations are not correct. Either way, this function will help you to find and resolve the problem by drawing what is going on in your physics system. To do this, you need tell it which part of the system to draw, and this is done by passing a value created from the bits stored in various "flag" constants:

Parameter.Name: flag
Parameter.Description: The flag value for showing different debug features

Function.Name: physics_world_draw_debug

Function.Description: As with all the physics functions, physics_world_gravity() will only work on an instance if the room has a physics world defined for it in the room editor or using physics_world_create(). It will then use the 0,0 defining point of the physics world to calculate the direction and strength of gravity based on the vector calculated from the xg and yg inputs. Here are some images to illustrate...

Parameter.Name: xg
Parameter.Description: The x component of the gravity vector

Parameter.Name: yg
Parameter.Description: The y component of the gravity vector

Function.Name: physics_world_gravity

Function.Description: Everything in GameMaker is based around steps and, normally, each event will only happen once per step. However, to get the necessary precision with the physics functions they are made to do several calculations each step which are called "iterations" the number of which are controlled by this function. The default number for the physics system is 10, but this can be changed to higher or lower depending how many times you want the physics to calculate each step, but it is recommended that you set this no lower than 5 and no higher than 30. You should also be aware that this function is dependent on the physics_world_update_speed() function.

Parameter.Name: y1
Parameter.Description: the iterations (per step) that the physics system will perform

Function.Name: physics_world_update_iterations

Function.Description: GameMaker updates things based on the room speed, so that if you set it to ,say, 30, GameMaker will run 30 steps in the course of a second. However, for the physics functions that may not be enough and you may want things to be updated at a slightly faster speed to increase stability or precision. To that end we use the function physics_world_update_speed() which sets the update speed for the physics system independently of the room speed. This means that you could have a room speed of 30, but set the physics to 60, effectively doubling the speed at which the physics system updates and performs its calculations compared to the speed at which the step are updated.

Parameter.Name: speed
Parameter.Description: the number of times per second that the physics system updates

Function.Name: physics_world_update_speed

Function.Description: This function returns a string containing the character with raw BYTE value set. This will not, and should not, be displayed, but it will save correctly to disk for use in encoding.

Parameter.Name: val
Parameter.Description: The raw byte value.

Function.Name: ansi_char

Function.Description: This function returns a string containing the character which relates to the input Unicode code for displaying. This character depends on the current drawing fonts character set code page and if no font is set, it will use the default code page for the machine.

Parameter.Name: val
Parameter.Description: The Unicode code value to get the string from

Function.Name: chr

Function.Description: This function will return a string of the text contained on the clipboard. if no text is stored it will return an empty string "".
Function.Name: clipboard_get_text

Function.Description: This function will return true if the clipboard contains text or false if it does not.
Function.Name: clipboard_has_text

Function.Description: This function will set the clipboard to hold the defined string. You can set it to an empty string "" to effectively clear the clipboard of text.

Parameter.Name: string
Parameter.Description: The text (as a string) to set the clipboard to hold.

Function.Name: clipboard_set_text

Function.Description: This function takes a single character input string and returns the Unicode (UTF8) value for that character. Note that when used with the keyboard_check* functions, the input string can only be one character in length and can only be a number from 0 to 9 or a capitalised Roman character from A to Z.

Parameter.Name: string
Parameter.Description: The string with which to find the Unicode code.

Function.Name: ord

Function.Description: This function can be used to turn a given string into a real number. When using this function, numbers, minus signs, decimal points and exponential parts in the string are taken into account, while other characters (such as letters) will cause an error to be thrown. If you know, or suspect, that a string may have other characters then you can use string_digits() to remove all non-numeric characters, before using this function to turn the resulting string into a real number.

Parameter.Name: string
Parameter.Description: The string to be converted to a real value.

Function.Name: real

Function.Description: With this function you can turn any value into a string. If the real number is an integer, it will be saved with no decimal places, otherwise, it will be saved with two decimal places. If you require more decimal places, then use the function string_format(). Also note that using this function on a variable storing an array, a data structure, or a struct will convert the contents of these variables into a string which can then be output to the console or saved to a file for debugging. You are also able to use a format string with "{x}" placeholders (i.e. {0},{1},...) where 'X' is the argument number after the format string (starting at 0).

Parameter.Name: val_or_format
Parameter.Description: The value to be turned into a string or a format string.
Values to replace the placeholders with.

Function.Name: string

Function.Description: Returns the raw byte value as a real value at a given position in the given string.

Parameter.Name: str
Parameter.Description: The string to check.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The position to get the byte from.

Function.Name: string_byte_at

Function.Description: This function returns the number of bytes in a string, but you should note that due to their being held as UTF8, this will not be equal to their string length.

Parameter.Name: string
Parameter.Description: The string to measure the number of bytes of.

Function.Name: string_byte_length

Function.Description: You can use this function to return a specific character at a specific position within a string, with the index starting at 1 for the first character. If no character is found or the string is shorter than the given index value, an empty string "" is returned, however if the given index is equal to or smaller than 0, then the first character of the string is returned.

Parameter.Name: str
Parameter.Description: The string to check.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The position to get the character from.

Function.Name: string_char_at

Function.Description: With this function you can easily select a number of characters from within a string to be copied to another one. The first character in a string is always indexed as 1 and not 0 as you may expect, so to copy (for example) the first five characters of string you would have string_copy(str, 1, 5). A further example is provided below.

Parameter.Name: str
Parameter.Description: The string to copy from.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The position of the first character in the string to copy from (numbered from 1)

Parameter.Name: count
Parameter.Description: The number of characters, starting from the position of the first, to copy

Function.Name: string_copy

Function.Description: This function will return the amount of times the given substring appears within a specific string. In this way you can check for how many times a single letter or a phrase is repeated in a section of stored text.

Parameter.Name: substr
Parameter.Description: The substring to check the string for.

Parameter.Name: str
Parameter.Description: The string to check.

Function.Name: string_count

Function.Description: You can use this function to remove a specific part of a string. So, you supply the input string and the start and end position within that string to remove characters (index starts at 1) and the function will return a new string without that section in it.

Parameter.Name: str
Parameter.Description: The string to copy and delete from.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The position of the first character to remove.

Parameter.Name: count
Parameter.Description: The number of characters to remove.

Function.Name: string_delete

Function.Description: You can use this function to parse a given string and get any numbers from it. For example, say you have this text - "I am 81 years old". With this function you would get a return string of "81".

Parameter.Name: string
Parameter.Description: The string to get the digits from.

Function.Name: string_digits

Function.Description: Turns a real number into a string using your own formatting, where you can choose how many "places" are saved to the string and how many decimal places are saved also. Both can be very handy, some games prefer to display a score as a set number of digits, while control over decimal places can be good for a high accuracy the two decimal places of string() cannot provide. If the number of places specified is greater than the value to be shown and/or the number plus the decimal places that have been specified is less than the total places, then spaces will be added before the value to make up the difference (see the example below). Zeros will be added to the right of the decimal point if the value given is less than the total and the number of decimal places to include. The default format is no extra spaces on the left, and only two decimal places on the right, eg "265.73".

Parameter.Name: val
Parameter.Description: The real number to be turned into a string.

Parameter.Name: tot
Parameter.Description: The total number of places of the main number to be shown. Zeroes or spaces will be inserted to match this.

Parameter.Name: dec
Parameter.Description: The number of decimal places to be included.

Function.Name: string_format

Function.Description: This function returns a string where the "#" symbol has been converted into a new line. So a string formatted as:

Parameter.Name: string
Parameter.Description: The string to convert over multiple lines

Function.Name: string_hash_to_newline

Function.Description: This function will return the height (in pixels) of the input string, taking into account the line separation and any line-breaks the text may have. It is very handy for calculating distances between text elements based on the tallest of the letters that make up the string as it would be drawn with draw_text() using the currently defined font.

Parameter.Name: string
Parameter.Description: The string to measure the height of.

Function.Name: string_height

Function.Description: This function will return the height (in pixels) of the input string, taking into account the line separation and line-break width (which is defined as the number of pixels that the string can occupy before a line break is inserted). It is very handy for calculating distances between text elements based on the tallest of the letters that make up the string as well as the actual string length itself when spread over several lines as it would be drawn with draw_text_ext() using the currently defined font. Separation and width can be set to -1 to get the default spacing.

Parameter.Name: string
Parameter.Description: The string to measure the height of.

Parameter.Name: sep
Parameter.Description: The distance in pixels between lines of text as if the string was being drawn.

Parameter.Name: w
Parameter.Description: The maximum width (in pixels) of the string before a line break as if the string was bring drawn.

Function.Name: string_height_ext

Function.Description: With this function you can create a new string made up of two strings, where one has been inserted into the other at a given position. It can be useful, for example, to add a user name into a predefined text and so make the player of your game feel more involved in the action. Keep in mind when calculating the position to insert into that strings are indexed from 1, so the first character in a string is 1 and not 0 as you may expect.

Parameter.Name: substr
Parameter.Description: The substring to be inserted.

Parameter.Name: str
Parameter.Description: The string to be copied.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The position in characters of the string to insert the substring.

Function.Name: string_insert

Function.Description: This function will return the character position of an instance of a sub-string within a string, searching from the end of the string to the beginning (so the reverse of string_pos(). The function will return 0 if the search string is not found, or the position of the first character of the search string if it is. Keep in mind that for legacy support strings are indexed from 1, so 1 is the first position in the string, not 0 as you may expect.

Parameter.Name: substr
Parameter.Description: The substring to look for in the string.

Parameter.Name: str
Parameter.Description: The string.

Function.Name: string_last_pos

Function.Description: This function will return the character position of an instance of a sub-string within a string, searching backwards through the string from the position given as the starting position. The function will return 0 if the search string is not found, or the position of the first character of the search string if it is. Keep in mind that for legacy support strings are indexed from 1, so 1 is the first position in the string, not 0 as you may expect.

Parameter.Name: substr
Parameter.Description: The substring to look for in the string.

Parameter.Name: str
Parameter.Description: The string.

Parameter.Name: start_pos
Parameter.Description: The starting position to search from.

Function.Name: string_last_pos_ext

Function.Description: This function returns the number of characters comprising a given string. It can be useful for things like working out when to limit a custom text entry's character length (eg: capping a player's name to 10 characters). Remember that this is different to string_width() in that it measures the number of characters in the string, not its width as drawn on the screen in pixels.

Parameter.Name: string
Parameter.Description: The string to measure the number of characters of.

Function.Name: string_length

Function.Description: With this function you can remove all characters that are not classed as letters. This is handy for preventing people from entering unwanted characters into a text entry (like entering "#" to force a new line).

Parameter.Name: string
Parameter.Description: The string to convert to letters.

Function.Name: string_letters

Function.Description: This function will return a copy of a given string with everything but its letters and digits removed, which means it can be used to remove any unwanted characters (like "#" or "?") from, for example, a login name or a password.

Parameter.Name: string
Parameter.Description: The string to convert to letters and digits.

Function.Name: string_lettersdigits

Function.Description: With this function you can force a string to contain only lower case characters.

Parameter.Name: string
Parameter.Description: The string to convert to lowercase.

Function.Name: string_lower

Function.Description: You can use this function to return a specific character code at a specific position within a string, with the index starting at 1 for the first character. If no character is found or the string is shorter than the value given to index, -1 is returned.

Parameter.Name: str
Parameter.Description: The string to check.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The position to get the character code from.

Function.Name: string_ord_at

Function.Description: This function will return the character position of an instance of a sub-string within a string, searching from the beginning of the string (to search from the end, use the function string_last_pos()). The function will return 0 if it's not found at all, or the position of the first character of the sub-string if it is found. Keep in mind that for legacy support strings are indexed from 1, so 1 is the first position in the string, not 0 as you may expect. One use for this is for filtering words that may be considered offensive, or for finding the correct place to insert some text into another string.

Parameter.Name: substr
Parameter.Description: The substring to look for in the string.

Parameter.Name: str
Parameter.Description: The string.

Function.Name: string_pos

Function.Description: This function will return the character position of an instance of a sub-string within a string, searching forwards through the string from the position given as the starting position. The function will return 0 if the search string is not found, or the position of the first character of the search string if it is. Keep in mind that for legacy support strings are indexed from 1, so 1 is the first position in the string, not 0 as you may expect.

Parameter.Name: substr
Parameter.Description: The substring to look for in the string.

Parameter.Name: str
Parameter.Description: The string.

Parameter.Name: start_pos
Parameter.Description: The starting position to search from.

Function.Name: string_pos_ext

Function.Description: This function simply returns the same string repeated a given number of times over itself.

Parameter.Name: str
Parameter.Description: The string to repeat.

Parameter.Name: count
Parameter.Description: The number of times to repeat the string.

Function.Name: string_repeat

Function.Description: You can use this function to parse a string looking for a specific part, which can then be replaced by the new string that you have specified.

Parameter.Name: str
Parameter.Description: The string to be copied.

Parameter.Name: substr
Parameter.Description: The substring within the string to be replaced.

Parameter.Name: newstr
Parameter.Description: The new substring to replace the previous one.

Function.Name: string_replace

Parameter.Name: str
Parameter.Description: The string to be copied.

Parameter.Name: substr
Parameter.Description: The substring within the string to be replaced in all instances.

Parameter.Name: newstr
Parameter.Description: The new substring to replace the previous one(s).

Function.Name: string_replace_all

Function.Description: This function sets a byte directly in a string (based on the UTF8 format) and returns a copy of the string with the changes.

Parameter.Name: str
Parameter.Description: The string to change the byte of.

Parameter.Name: pos
Parameter.Description: The position within the string (starting at 1) to change the byte of.

Parameter.Name: byte
Parameter.Description: The new byte value.

Function.Name: string_set_byte_at

Function.Description: With this function you can force a string to contain only upper case characters.

Parameter.Name: string
Parameter.Description: The string to convert to uppercase.

Function.Name: string_upper

Function.Description: This function will return the width (in pixels) of the input string, taking into account any line-breaks the text may have. It is very handy for calculating distances between text elements based on the total width of the letters that make up the string as it would be drawn with draw_text() using the currently defined font.

Parameter.Name: string
Parameter.Description: The string to measure the width of.

Function.Name: string_width

Function.Description: This function will return the maximum width (in pixels) of the input string, taking into account the line separation and line-break width (which is defined as the number of pixels that the string can occupy before a line break is inserted). It is very handy for calculating distances between text elements based on the maximum width of a string that is split over several lines as it would be drawn with draw_text_ext() using the currently defined font. Separation and width can be set to -1 to get the default spacing.

Parameter.Name: string
Parameter.Description: The string to measure the width of.

Parameter.Name: sep
Parameter.Description: The distance in pixels between lines of text as if the string was being drawn.

Parameter.Name: w
Parameter.Description: The maximum width (in pixels) of the string before a line break as if the string was bring drawn.

Function.Name: string_width_ext

Function.Description: This function returns a new string using a format string with placeholder information and an array of values. The placeholders should follow the format "{x}" where x is the index of the value in the array that it should be replaced with.

Parameter.Name: format
Parameter.Description: The input string format.

Parameter.Name: val_array
Parameter.Description: An array of values to replace the placeholders.

Function.Name: string_ext

Function.Description: This function removes whitespace from the beginning of a string (left). You can optionally provide an array of strings to be used for trimming if you want to remove something other than whitespaces.

Parameter.Description: The input string.

Parameter.Description: An array of strings to be used during trimming.

Function.Description: This function removes whitespace from the end of a string (right). You can optionally provide an array of strings to be used for trimming if you want to remove something other than whitespaces.

Parameter.Name: str
Parameter.Description: The input string.

Parameter.Name: substrs
Parameter.Description: An array of strings to be used during trimming.

Function.Name: string_trim_end

Function.Description: This function removes whitespace from both ends of a string and returns a new string, without modifying the original string. You can optionally provide an array of strings to be used for trimming if you want to remove something other than whitespaces.

Parameter.Name: str
Parameter.Description: The input string.

Parameter.Name: substrs
Parameter.Description: An array of strings to be used during trimming.

Function.Name: string_trim

Function.Description: This function determines whether a string begins with the characters of a specified string, returning true or false as appropriate.

Parameter.Name: str
Parameter.Description: The input string.

Parameter.Name: substr
Parameter.Description: The string to check against.

Function.Name: string_starts_with

Function.Description: This function determines whether a string ends with the characters of a specified string, returning true or false as appropriate.

Parameter.Name: str
Parameter.Description: The input string.

Parameter.Name: substr
Parameter.Description: The string to check against.

Parameter.Name: str
Parameter.Description: The input string.

Parameter.Name: delimiter
Parameter.Description: The delimiter string to search for.

Parameter.Name: remove_empty
Parameter.Description: Removes empty entries from the output array.

Parameter.Name: max_splits
Parameter.Description: The maximum number of splits that are allowed.

Function.Name: string_split

Parameter.Name: str
Parameter.Description: The input string.

Parameter.Name: delimiter_array
Parameter.Description: An array of delimiter strings to search for.

Parameter.Name: remove_empty
Parameter.Description: Removes empty entries from the output array.

Parameter.Name: max_splits
Parameter.Description: The maximum number of splits that are allowed.

Function.Description: This function joins a set of arguments using the provided delimiter, non-string values will be converted to string.

Parameter.Name: delimiter
Parameter.Description: The delimiter to use when joining the values.
The values be joined using the delimiter.

Parameter.Description: The delimiter to use when joining the values.

Parameter.Name: values_array
Parameter.Description: An array of values be joined using the delimiter.

Parameter.Name: offset
Parameter.Description: The offset of the range (allows negative values, from end of string).

Parameter.Name: length
Parameter.Description: The number of elements to join (allows negative values, reverse traversing).

Function.Description: This function concatenates a set of arguments, non-string values will be converted to string.

Parameter.Description: An array of values be concatenated.

Parameter.Description: The offset of the range (allows negative values, from end of string).

Parameter.Name: length
Parameter.Description: The number of elements to concatenate (allows negative values, reverse traversing).

Function.Name: string_concat_ext

Function.Description: This function iterates over each character of a string calling a provided function. It allows to specify a start position (1-based) and a length.

Parameter.Description: The string to iterate over.

Parameter.Name: func
Parameter.Description: A function to be called for each character in range (allows arguments 'char' and 'pos').

Parameter.Name: pos
Parameter.Description: The position to start the iteration from (allows negative values, from end of string).

Parameter.Name: length
Parameter.Description: The number of iterations to execute (allows negative values, reverse traversing).

Function.Name: string_foreach

Function.Description: With this function you can copy all or part of an array into another array at any position. You need to supply both the source and the destination arrays (both need to have been created previously), as well as a position within the source array to copy from and a position within the destination array to copy to. Finally you need to specify the length of the array (or the length of the part that you want) to copy. If the data being copied exceeds the length of the destination array, the array will be extended to accept the data.

Parameter.Name: dest
Parameter.Description: The ID of the array to copy to.

Parameter.Name: dest_index
Parameter.Description: The index within the array to copy to.

Parameter.Name: src
Parameter.Description: The ID of the array to copy from.

Parameter.Name: src_index
Parameter.Description: The index with the array to start copying from.

Parameter.Name: length
Parameter.Description: The length (number of array indices) to copy.

Function.Name: array_copy

Function.Description: With this function you can create a 1D array of a given size. You tell the function the length of the array to create, and it will return the "handle" for the array which you can then assign to a variable. Arrays created in this way will have each entry initialised to 0 unless you specify an (optional) initialisation value. If you do supply the extra value for initialising the array, then all indices within the new array will be set to that instead of 0, but note that the function will have a greater performance overhead in this case.

Parameter.Name: size
Parameter.Description: The size of the array to create.

Parameter.Name: value
Parameter.Description: The value to use to initialise all array indices (optional).

Function.Name: array_create

Function.Description: With this function you can delete a value (or values) from an array at any given position. The function requires you to provide a variable that holds the array, the index (position) in the array to delete from, as well as the number of values to delete.

Parameter.Name: array
Parameter.Description: The variable that holds the array.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index (position) in the array to delete the value(s) from.

Parameter.Name: number
Parameter.Description: The number of values to delete.

Function.Name: array_delete

Function.Description: With this function you can check to see if two arrays are equal (equivalent or the same). You give the two arrays to check, and the function will return true if they are equal (either equivalent or the same) or false if they are not. Note that this is not the same as checking if two arrays are the same using ==, which will not check to see if the two arrays hold equivalent values, but only to see if the arrays are referencing the same initial array. For example:

Parameter.Name: array1
Parameter.Description: The index of the first array.

Parameter.Name: array2
Parameter.Description: The index of the second array.

Function.Name: array_equals

Function.Description: With this function you can retrieve the value from an index in an array. The function requires you to provide a variable that holds the array and the index to get the value from within that array. Note that if the array index given is out of bounds then the game will crash with an error. This function can also be used for multi-dimension arrays, as long as you specify which dimension you want to get when you supply the array index, following this pattern:

Parameter.Name: array
Parameter.Description: The variable that holds the array.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the array to get the value from.

Function.Name: array_get

Function.Description: With this function you can insert a value (or values) into an array at any given position. The function requires you to provide a variable that holds the array, the index (position) in the array to insert at, as well as at least one value to insert, although you can optionally provide further arguments and they will all be inserted into the array in consecutive order from the given index.

Parameter.Description: The variable that holds the array.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index (position) in the array to insert the value(s)
The value to insert

You supply the array index value and the function will return an integer value representing the number of entries the array contains. This function can also be used for multi-dimension arrays, as long as you specify which dimension you want to get the length of when you supply the array index, following this pattern:

Parameter.Description: The variable that holds the array.

The function requires you to provide a variable that holds the array as well as at least one value to push, although you can optionally provide further arguments and they will all be pushed onto the array in consecutive order.

The value to push onto the end of the array

You supply the array to be resized as well as the new number of indices for the array, and the function will resize that array. Note that this function is designed for resizing an array down to a smaller length as you can resize up by simply setting a new index in the array. That said, if you do use it to size up an array, any new indices will be set to the default value of 0.

Parameter.Name: array
Parameter.Description: The index of the array to resize.

Parameter.Name: new_size
Parameter.Description: The new size for the array (an integer, starting from 0).

The function requires you to provide a variable that holds the array as well as the index to set and the value to set it to. This function can also be used for multi-dimension arrays, as long as you specify which dimension you want to set when you supply the array index, following this pattern:

Parameter.Name: array
Parameter.Description: The variable that holds the array.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the array to set the value for.

Parameter.Name: value
Parameter.Description: The value to set.

Function.Description: With this function you can sort an array in ascending order or descending order or using a custom function to define the sort order. The function requires you to provide the array to sort, and then either of the following:

Parameter.Description: The variable that holds the array.

Function.Description: With this function you can shuffle an array (or subsection) in place, nothing is returned

Parameter.Description: The variable that holds the array.

Parameter.Description: The offset to be used when shuffling the array. Negative values will count from the end of the array. Defaults to 0.

The function will return a method which can be called from the variable it is assigned to (see the code example below). It is worth noting that you can bind built-in functions as well as user defined functions, and you can also supply undefined as the instance/struct argument meaning that the current self scope will be used for the binding.

Parameter.Description: The name of the struct variable to check for (as a string)

Function.Name: struct_foreach

Function.Description: With this function you can get the value from a given named variable within a struct. You supply the struct reference as well as the name of the variable to get the value of as a string (see example code below). The function will return the value held by the variable or undefined if the named variable does not exist.

Parameter.Name: struct
Parameter.Description: The struct reference to use

Parameter.Name: name
Parameter.Description: The name of the variable to get (as a string)

Function.Name: struct_get

Function.Description: With this function you can get the value from a given named variable within a struct. You supply the struct reference as well as the hash of the variable to get the value of (returned from 'variable_get_hash'). The function will return the value held by the variable or undefined if the named variable does not exist.

Parameter.Name: struct
Parameter.Description: The struct reference to use

Parameter.Name: hash
Parameter.Description: The hash of the variable to get (returned from 'variable_get_hash')

Function.Name: struct_get_from_hash

Function.Description: With this function you can retrieve an array populated with the variable names from a struct. You pass in the struct reference to check, and each entry in the array will be a string of the variable names that the struct contains.

Parameter.Name: struct
Parameter.Description: The struct reference to check.

Function.Name: struct_get_names

Function.Description: With this function you can find the total number number of variables defined for a struct. You supply the struct ID to check, and the function will return an integer value for the number of variables encountered, or (if no struct of the given ID exists) -1.

Parameter.Name: struct_id
Parameter.Description: The unique ID value of the struct to check.

Function.Name: struct_names_count

Function.Description: With this function you can remove a variable from a struct. You supply the struct ID to remove the variable from and the string name of the variable to be removed.

Parameter.Name: struct
Parameter.Description: The struct reference to remove the variable from

Parameter.Name: name
Parameter.Description: The name of the variable to remove (as a string)

Function.Name: struct_remove

Function.Description: With this function you can set the value of a given variable in a struct. You supply the struct reference as well as the name of the variable to set the value of as a string (see example code below), and then finally the value to set (can be any valid data type). If the variable does not exist already in the struct it will be created and then assigned the value.

Parameter.Name: struct
Parameter.Description: The struct reference to set

Parameter.Name: name
Parameter.Description: The name of the variable to set (as a string)

Parameter.Name: val
Parameter.Description: The value to set the variable to

Function.Name: struct_set

Function.Description: With this function you can set the value of a given variable in a struct. You supply the struct reference as well as the hash of the variable to set the value of (returned from 'variable_get_hash'), and then finally the value to set (can be any valid data type). If the variable does not exist already in the struct it will be created and then assigned the value.

Parameter.Name: struct
Parameter.Description: The struct reference to set

Parameter.Name: hash
Parameter.Description: The hash of the variable to set (returned from 'variable_get_hash')

Parameter.Name: val
Parameter.Description: The value to set the variable to

Function.Name: struct_set_from_hash

Function.Description: This function will send the specified text to the analytics provider that you have set up through the HTML5 Game Options. This function can be used to create a custom analytic to track something outside of the scope of the provider being used.

Parameter.Name: string
Parameter.Description: A string to send to the provider

Function.Name: analytics_event

Function.Description: This function will send the specified text to the analytics provider that you have set up through the HTML5 Game Options. This function can be used to create a custom analytic to track something outside of the scope of the provider being used, and will also accept custom parameter/value pairs, where the parameter is a string and the value a real number. For Google Analytics, you can only add in one extra pair while Flurry will accept up to 7.

Parameter.Name: string
Parameter.Description: A string to send to the provider.

Parameter.Name: string_param[0 -9]
Parameter.Description: The parameter to send (a string).

Parameter.Name: value[0 - 9]
Parameter.Description: The value of the parameter (a real number).

Function.Name: analytics_event_ext

Function.Description: With this function you can set whether the browser window should capture all input (set it to false) or whether the game should capture the input (set it to true). Note that this function is for use with the HTML5 module only.
Function.Name: browser_input_capture

Function.Description: With this function you can create a custom, clickable, icon that acts as a "button" outside of the game canvas, but within the browser window itself. The function will return an id value which must be stored in a variable to be used in all further button functions that reference the new icon. This function is very useful to prevent the browser creating a pop-up window when clicking on the button as it is all done through GameMaker itself.

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x position within the window.

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y position within the window.

Parameter.Name: tpe
Parameter.Description: The texture page entry for the sprite to be used.

Parameter.Name: url
Parameter.Description: The URL (website address) to link to, or the script to be run.

Parameter.Name: target
Parameter.Description: This is the target area to open the URL in (see description).

Parameter.Name: params
Parameter.Description: The various parameters for the icon (see description).

Function.Name: clickable_add

Function.Description: With this function you can create a custom, clickable, icon that acts as a "button" outside of the game canvas, but within the browser window itself. The function will return an id value which must be stored in a variable to be used in all further button functions that reference the new icon. This function is very useful to prevent the browser creating a pop-up window when clicking on the button as it is all done through GameMaker itself.

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x position within the window.

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y position within the window.

Parameter.Name: tpe
Parameter.Description: The texture page entry for the sprite to be used.

Parameter.Name: url
Parameter.Description: The URL (website address) to link to, or the script to be run.

Parameter.Name: target
Parameter.Description: This is the target area to open the URL in (see description).

Parameter.Name: params
Parameter.Description: The various parameters for the icon (see description).

Parameter.Name: alpha
Parameter.Description: The image alpha of the icon (default 1).

Parameter.Name: scale
Parameter.Description: The scale of the icon (default 1).

Function.Name: clickable_add_ext

Function.Description: With this function you can change the sprite and position of a clickable icon previously created with clickable_add(). Please note that the position is based on the window, not the canvas, (0,0) position and that the sprite must be referenced directly from the texture page (see: sprite_get_tpe()).

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the clickable icon to change.

Parameter.Name: tpe
Parameter.Description: The texture page entry for the sprite to be used.

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The new x position within the window.

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The new y position within the window.

Function.Name: clickable_change

Function.Description: With this function you can change the sprite and position of a clickable icon previously created with clickable_add(). Bear in mind that the position is based on the window, not the canvas, (0,0) position and that the sprite must be referenced directly from the texture page (see: sprite_get_tpe()). This function also permits you to change the scale of the sprite used (as a multiplier so that 1 is the default, 0.5 would be half and 2 would be double) and the alpha value from 0 (fully transparent) to 1 (fully opaque) for the final icon on the screen.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the clickable icon to change.

Parameter.Name: tpe
Parameter.Description: The texture page entry for the sprite to be used

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The new x position within the window.

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The new y position within the window.

Parameter.Name: scale
Parameter.Description: The scale of the icon (default 1).

Parameter.Name: alpha
Parameter.Description: The image alpha of the icon (default 1).

Function.Name: clickable_change_ext

Function.Description: This function must be used to remove a clickable icon previously created with clickable_add() from the game window.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: Index of the clickable icon to remove.

Function.Name: clickable_delete

Function.Description: This function returns whether a clickable DOM icon has been created with the specified index exists or not. Please note, that the value used for checking must have been initialised previously or else you will get an error causing GameMaker to close.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the clickable to check.

Function.Name: clickable_exists

Function.Description: This function lets you set the CSS style properties for the given button via the key/value pairs in the provided DS Map. You need to have previously created the both the button element (using clickable_add()) and the DS Map and supply the stored indices to each as arguments.

Parameter.Name: index
Parameter.Description: The index of the clickable icon to style.

Parameter.Name: map
Parameter.Description: The index of the DS Map to set the style from.

Function.Name: clickable_set_style

Function.Description: You can use this to get the domain where your HTML5 game is being played.
Function.Name: url_get_domain

Function.Description: This will open the specified URL on the browser of the chosen target device, or, if you are using the HTML5 module, in the currently open browser.

Parameter.Name: url
Parameter.Description: The URL (website address) to link to.

Function.Name: url_open

Function.Description: This will open the specified URL on the browser of the chosen target device, or, if you are using the HTML5 module, in the currently open browser. The "target" parameter that you specify is the same as the standard JavaScript "name" value when you use the open() method, and you should be aware that all but "_self" may result in the browser blocking, or asking the user if they wish to allow it.

Parameter.Name: url
Parameter.Description: The URL (website address) to link to.

Parameter.Name: target
Parameter.Description: This is the target area to open the URL in.

Function.Name: url_open_ext

Function.Description: This will open the specified URL on the browser of the chosen target device, or, if you are using the HTML5 module, in the currently open browser. The "target" parameter that you specify is the same as the standard JavaScript "name" value when you use the open() method (be aware that all but "_self" may result in the browser blocking, or asking the user if they wish to allow it) and the "options" is the same as the JavaScript "specs" parameter for controlling what properties the new window/tab should display (not all browsers may support all features).

Parameter.Name: url
Parameter.Description: The URL (website address) to link to.

Parameter.Name: target
Parameter.Description: This is the target area to open the URL in (see description).

Parameter.Name: options
Parameter.Description: Standard browser options (see description).

Function.Name: url_open_full

Function.Description: This function sets the seed to a random value. Should you need to keep a consistent value over a number of runs of a game, you should be using random_set_seed(). Please note, that when using the random number functions in GameMaker the initial seed is always the same, as this makes tracing errors and debugging far easier. Should you wish to test with true random, you should call this function at the start of your game. The function will return the new randomised seed value (an unsigned 32bit integer).
Function.Name: randomize

Function.Description: The dot product is a value expressing the angular relationship between two vectors and is found by taking two vectors, multiplying them together and then adding the results. The name "dot product" is derived from the centered dot "" that is often used to designate this operation (the alternative name "scalar product" emphasizes the scalar rather than vector nature of the result).

Parameter.Name: x1
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of the first vector.

Parameter.Name: y1
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of the first vector.

Parameter.Name: x2
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of the second vector.

Parameter.Name: y2
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of the second vector.

Function.Name: dot_product_normalized

Function.Description: The dot product is a value expressing the angular relationship between two vectors and is found by taking two vectors, multiplying them together and then adding the results. The name "dot product" is derived from the centered dot "" that is often used to designate this operation (the alternative name "scalar product" emphasizes the scalar rather than vector nature of the result).

Parameter.Name: x1
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of the first vector.

Parameter.Name: y1
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of the first vector.

Parameter.Name: z1
Parameter.Description: The z coordinate of the first vector.

Parameter.Name: x2
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of the second vector.

Parameter.Name: y2
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of the second vector.

Parameter.Name: z2
Parameter.Description: The z coordinate of the second vector.

Function.Name: dot_product_3d_normalized

Function.Description: With this function you can set the base draw colour for the game. This value will affect all further drawing where appropriate, including fonts, forms, primitives and 3D. If any of those assets are drawn with their own colour value changed, this value will be ignored.

Parameter.Name: col
Parameter.Description: The colour to set for drawing.

Function.Name: draw_set_color

Function.Description: This function returns the current draw colour which is used for drawing forms, text, primitives and un-textured 3D models. This can be set with the draw_set_color() function.
Function.Name: draw_get_color

Function.Description: With this function you can take two colours and then merge them together to make a new colour. The amount of each of the component colours can be defined by changing the "amount" argument, where a value of 0 will return the first colour (col1), a value of 1 will return the second colour (col2) and a value in between will return the corresponding mix. For example, a value of 0.5 will mix the two colours equally. The following image illustrates how this works by merging the colours red and blue together:

Parameter.Name: col1
Parameter.Description: The first colour to merge

Parameter.Name: col2
Parameter.Description: The second colour to merge

Parameter.Name: amount
Parameter.Description: How much of each colour should be merged. For example, 0 will return col1, 1 will return col2, and 0.5 would return a merge of both colours equally

Function.Name: merge_color

Function.Description: GameMaker provides this function (as well as others) to permit the user to make their own colours. This particular function takes three component parts, the red, the green and the blue components of the colour that you wish to make. These values are taken as being between 0 and 255 so you can make 16,777,216 (256*256*256) colours with this! Below you can see an image of how these components look when separated:

Parameter.Name: red
Parameter.Description: The red component of the colour

Parameter.Name: green
Parameter.Description: The green component of the colour

Parameter.Name: blue
Parameter.Description: The blue component of the colour

Function.Name: make_color_rgb

Function.Description: GameMaker provides this function (as well as others) to permit the user to make their own colours. This particular function takes three component parts, the hue, the saturation and the value (also know as "luminosity") to create the colour desired. These values are taken as being between 0 and 255 so you can make 16,777,216 (256*256*256) colours with this! Below you can see an image of how these components look when separated:

Parameter.Name: hue
Parameter.Description: The hue of the colour

Parameter.Name: sat
Parameter.Description: How saturated the colour is

Parameter.Name: val
Parameter.Description: How dark the colour is

Function.Name: make_color_hsv

Function.Description: This function returns the amount of red used to make the given color, with the value being between 0 and 255, where 0 is no red and 255 is all red. The following image illustrates this:

Parameter.Name: col
Parameter.Description: The color to check

Function.Name: color_get_red

Function.Description: This function returns the amount of green used to make the given color, with the value being between 0 and 255, where 0 is no green and 255 is all green. The following image illustrates this:

Parameter.Name: col
Parameter.Description: The color to check

Function.Name: color_get_green

Function.Description: This function returns the amount of blue used to make the given color, with the value being between 0 and 255, where 0 is no blue and 255 is all blue. The following image illustrates this:

Parameter.Name: col
Parameter.Description: The color to check

Function.Name: color_get_blue

Function.Description: This function will return the hue of the given color. This is the "pure" color tone which is part of the hue, saturation and value (luminosity) method for defining a color. The following image illustrates how this value corresponds to the HSV scale of color:

Parameter.Name: col
Parameter.Description: The color to check

Function.Name: color_get_hue

Function.Description: This function will return the saturation of the given color. This is the amount of the color tone that is mixed into the final color and is part of the hue, saturation and value (luminosity) method for defining a color. The following image illustrates how this value corresponds to the HSV scale of color:

Parameter.Name: col
Parameter.Description: The color to check

Function.Name: color_get_saturation

Function.Description: This function will return the value (luminosity) of the given color. This is the amount of the "light" that is mixed into the final color and is part of the hue, saturation and value method for defining a color. The following image illustrates how this value corresponds to the HSV scale of color:

Parameter.Name: col
Parameter.Description: The colour to check

Function.Description: This function is a combination of the base draw_text() function with the draw_text_ext(), draw_text_transformed() and draw_text_colour() functions. As such, this is the most general of all functions for drawing text and gives a large amount of flexibility when drawing. Note that the "width" argument is based on a scale of 1, so if the scale is different, this value should be changed proportionally. For example, if the base width for a line break is 300 and you set the scale to 2, then the text will appear wrong, over-running the given width. Instead you should have set the width to 150 to compensate the scaling.

Parameter.Description: The colour of the point.

The colour settings will over-ride the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour(). Please note that the line being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.

Parameter.Name: y1

Parameter.Description: The colour of the end of the line.

The colour settings will over-ride the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour(). Please note that the line being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.

Parameter.Name: x1
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of the start of the line.

Parameter.Name: y1
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of the start of the line.

Parameter.Name: x2
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of the end of the line.

Parameter.Name: y2
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of the end of the line.

Parameter.Description: The width in pixels of the line.

Parameter.Name: col1
Parameter.Description: The colour of the start of the line.

Parameter.Name: col2
Parameter.Description: The colour of the end of the line.

Function.Description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a rectangle or a filled rectangle by defining an area where the (x1,y1) position is the top left corner and the (x2,y2) position is the bottom right corner. If it is filled you can define the individual colours for each corner point and if these colours are not the same, you will get a gradient effect from one to the other (the colour settings will over-ride the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour()). Please note that the rectangle being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y, or width or height) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.

Parameter.Name: x1
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of the left of the rectangle.

Parameter.Name: y1
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of the top of the rectangle.

Parameter.Name: x2
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of the right of the rectangle.

Parameter.Name: y2
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of the bottom of the rectangle.

Parameter.Name: col1
Parameter.Description: The colour of the top left corner.

Parameter.Name: col2
Parameter.Description: The colour of the top right corner.

Parameter.Name: col3
Parameter.Description: The colour of the bottom right corner.

Parameter.Name: col4
Parameter.Description: The colour of the bottom left corner.

Parameter.Name: outline
Parameter.Description: Whether the rectangle is an outline (true) or filled in (false).

Function.Name: draw_rectangle_color

Function.Description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a rounded rectangle or a filled rounded rectangle where the (x1,y1) position is the top left corner and the (x2,y2) position is the bottom right corner. If it is filled you can define the individual colours for the centre and the edges, and if these colours are not the same, you will get a gradient effect from one to the other (the colour settings will over-ride the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour()).You can define how precise the drawing of the corners is with the function draw_set_circle_precision(), but the corners are always drawn with a fixed radius. Should you need to change the corner radius you should use the function draw_roundrect_colour_ext(). Please note that the rectangle being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y, or width or height) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.

Parameter.Name: x1
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of the left of the rounded rectangle.

Parameter.Name: y1
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of the top of the rounded rectangle.

Parameter.Name: x2
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of the right of the rounded rectangle.

Parameter.Name: y2
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of the bottom of the rounded rectangle.

Parameter.Name: col1
Parameter.Description: The center colour.

Parameter.Name: col2
Parameter.Description: The outside edge colour.

Parameter.Name: outline
Parameter.Description: Whether the rectangle is an outline (true) or filled in (false).

Function.Name: draw_roundrect_color

Function.Description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a rounded rectangle or a filled rounded rectangle where the (x1,y1) position is the top left corner and the (x2,y2) position is the bottom right corner. If the rectangle is filled, then the colour arguments will be used to generate a colour gradient from the centre to the edges, where colour 1 is the centre colour and colour 2 the edge colour. You must also supply radius values for the x and y axis (in pixels) and the corners will be rounded by these amounts. You can define how precise the drawing of the corners is with the function draw_set_circle_precision(). Please note that the rectangle being drawn may need different values (+/-1 on the x, y, or width or height) to be drawn with the desired dimensions due to differences across the various supported platforms.

Parameter.Name: x1
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of the left of the rounded rectangle.

Parameter.Name: y1
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of the top of the rounded rectangle.

Parameter.Name: x2
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of the right of the rounded rectangle.

Parameter.Name: y2
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of the bottom of the rounded rectangle.

Parameter.Name: xrad
Parameter.Description: The radius of the curve along the x axis from the rectangle corners.

Parameter.Name: yrad
Parameter.Description: The radius of the curve along the y axis from the rectangle corners.

Parameter.Name: col1
Parameter.Description: The center colour.

Parameter.Name: col2
Parameter.Description: The outside edge colour.

Parameter.Name: outline
Parameter.Description: Whether the rectangle is an outline (true) or filled in (false).

Function.Name: draw_roundrect_color_ext

Function.Description: With this function you can draw either an outline of a circle or a filled circle, and if it is filled you can define the interior and exterior fill colours. If these colours are not the same, you will get a gradient effect from one to the other and the colour settings will over-ride the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour(). You can define how precise the drawing is with the function draw_set_circle_precision().

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of the center of the circle.

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of the center of the circle.

Parameter.Name: r
Parameter.Description: The radius (distance from center to edge) of the circle in pixels.

Parameter.Name: col1
Parameter.Description: The colour at the center of the circle.

Parameter.Name: col2
Parameter.Description: The colour at the edge of the circle.

Parameter.Name: outline
Parameter.Description: Whether the circle is an outline (true) or not (false). If true, col1 is irrelevant.

Function.Name: draw_circle_color

Function.Description: With this function you can draw either an outline of an ellipse or a filled ellipse by defining a rectangular area that will then have the ellipse created to fit. If it is filled you can define the interior and exterior fill colours. If these colours are not the same, you will get a gradient effect from one to the other (the colour settings will over-ride the base colour set with the function draw_set_colour()). You can define how precise the drawing is with the function draw_set_circle_precision().

Parameter.Name: x1
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of the left of the ellipse.

Parameter.Name: y1
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of the top of the ellipse.

Parameter.Name: x2
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of the right of the ellipse.

Parameter.Name: y2
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of the bottom of the ellipse.

Parameter.Name: col1
Parameter.Description: The colour of the center.

Parameter.Name: col2
Parameter.Description: The colour of the edge.

Parameter.Name: outline
Parameter.Description: Whether the ellipse is an outline (true) or filled in (false).

Function.Name: draw_ellipse_color

Function.Description: This function defines the position of a vertex for a primitive, with its own colour and alpha setting. The final look of the primitive will depend on the primitive type chosen to draw and the order with which you add the vertexes to it (see draw_primitive_begin() for more information) and the vertexes with different colours and alphas will blend smoothly from one to the other. To end and draw the primitive you must call draw_primitive_end().

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of the vertex.

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of the vertex.

Parameter.Name: col
Parameter.Description: The colour to draw this vertex with.

Parameter.Name: alpha
Parameter.Description: The alpha to draw this vertex with (0-1).

Function.Name: draw_vertex_color

Function.Description: This function lets you pre-cache a character glyph from a font. If you don't pre-cache a character using this function, it's automatically cached before it's drawn for the first time.

Parameter.Name: font
Parameter.Description: The font to cache a character or glyph from

Parameter.Name: glyph_index
Parameter.Description: The index (or character code) of the glyph to cache (see ord/string_ord_at)

Function.Name: font_cache_glyph

Function.Description: This function defines the position of a textured vertex for a primitive. The final look of the primitive will depend on the primitive type chosen to draw (See draw_primitive_begin() for more information), the order with which you add the vertices to it, the position of the start and end points that you give for the texture sample and the colour and alpha values that you have set. To maintain the texture appearance while changing only the alpha, a value of -1 (or c_white) may be used for the colour argument. To end and draw the primitive you must call draw_primitive_end().

Parameter.Name: x
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate of the vertex.

Parameter.Name: y
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate of the vertex.

Parameter.Name: xtex
Parameter.Description: The x coordinate within the texture.

Parameter.Name: ytex
Parameter.Description: The y coordinate within the texture.

Parameter.Name: col
Parameter.Description: The colour to blend with the texture at this vertex (-1 or c_white for no blending).

Parameter.Name: alpha
Parameter.Description: The alpha to draw this vertex with (0-1).

Function.Name: draw_vertex_texture_color

Parameter.Description: The colour to set the region.

Function.Description: This function is used to set a particle type to be a single colour for the total duration of the lifetime of each individual particle.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to change.

Parameter.Name: colour1
Parameter.Description: The single colour to make the particle type.

Function.Description: This function can be used to set a two colour gradient for each particle created of the given type. The first colour is that which all particles will start with, and the second colour is the one on which the particle will end with, and a smooth gradient change will occur to the colour over the particles lifetime from one colour to the other.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to change.

Parameter.Name: colour1
Parameter.Description: The colour the particle will start at.

Parameter.Name: colour2
Parameter.Description: The colour the particle will end at.

Function.Name: part_type_color2

Function.Description: This function can be used to set a three colour gradient for each particle created of the given type. The first colour is that which all particles will start with, and the second colour is the one that will be blended to half way through its lifetime and the third colour is the one with which the particle will end with. A smooth gradient change will occur through the colours over the particles lifetime from one colour to the other.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to change.

Parameter.Name: colour1
Parameter.Description: The colour the particle will start at.

Parameter.Name: colour2
Parameter.Description: The colour the particle will be halfway through its lifespan.

Parameter.Name: colour3
Parameter.Description: The colour the particle will end at.

Function.Name: part_type_color3

Function.Description: With this function you can set the given particle type to be a random blend of two colours.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to change.

Parameter.Name: colour1
Parameter.Description: The first colour the blend will take from.

Parameter.Name: colour2
Parameter.Description: The second colour the blend will take from.

Function.Name: part_type_color_mix

Function.Description: With this function you can set the mix of red, green and blue colours for all particles created of the given type. You supply a minimum value and a maximum value for each of the three components and the particles created will have a random colour based on the given range of parameters. All values must be between 0 and 255.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to change.

Parameter.Name: rmin
Parameter.Description: The minimum the final colour's red component can be.

Parameter.Name: rmax
Parameter.Description: The maximum the final colour's red component can be.

Parameter.Name: gmin
Parameter.Description: The minimum the final colour's green component can be.

Parameter.Name: gmax
Parameter.Description: The maximum the final colour's green component can be.

Parameter.Name: bmin
Parameter.Description: The minimum the final colour's blue component can be.

Parameter.Name: bmax
Parameter.Description: The maximum the final colour's blue component can be.

Function.Name: part_type_color_rgb

Function.Description: With this function you can set a hue, saturation and value range for all particles of the given type. You supply a minimum value and a maximum value for each of the three components and the particles created will have a random colour based on the given range of parameters. In this way you can create particles of the same hue but different saturations, or of different hues but the same value (luminosity) etc... All values must be between 0 and 255.

Parameter.Name: ind
Parameter.Description: The index of the particle type to change.

Parameter.Name: hmin
Parameter.Description: The minimum the final colour's hue component can be.

Parameter.Name: hmax
Parameter.Description: The maximum the final colour's hue component can be.

Parameter.Name: smin
Parameter.Description: The minimum the final colour's saturation component can be.

Parameter.Name: smax
Parameter.Description: The maximum the final colour's saturation component can be.

Parameter.Name: vmin
Parameter.Description: The minimum the final colour's value component can be.

Parameter.Name: vmax
Parameter.Description: The maximum the final colour's value component can be.

Function.Name: part_type_color_hsv

You can also colour the particles "on the fly" as they are created with this function, and this colour will over-ride the predefined colour of the particle, but it does not blend this colour over the particles lifetime. Note that you must have created the particle system and the particle type previously for this function to be used.

Function.Description: With this function you can switch on or off the colour channels and the alpha channel for all further drawing. For example, you can use this function to create alpha-channel only surfaces (switch off the RGB writing before using the surface), or to create special effects while drawing to the screen. The default value for each of the components is true, and can be supplied as either four unique arguments or as a 4 element 1D array with the following elements in it which will be either true (enabled) or false (disabled):

The function needs a buffer to store the data in and will take either a colour constant, or a hex value (using the standard GameMaker format of BGR, eg: $FF0000 for blue) as well as an alpha value from 0 (transparent) to 1 (fully opaque).
